speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS) ACT 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to be the first speaker for the first sitting of the House in 1993, and I hope all members on the other side spent a pleasant holiday in their constituencies.

February 1, 1993
Government Orders
My own constituents were asking me when there would be an election, because nearly everyone I met during the holidays wanted at least to be able to vote against this government and have an opportunity to do so very shortly.
We now see a government here in the House introducing bills that are unacceptable to most Canadians. Canadians would like to have a chance to say no to this government now. And I hope that when the Prime Minister considers the matter this week, he will consider the interests of Canadians.

I have to return to the bill before us. As I was saying at the time of the adjournment on this debate on December 4, the bill is unacceptable to this party, primarily because of the change relating to the Canada Council and SSHRC, the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council.
I note also in the bill that it is stated that part of the purpose of this bill is to transfer certain functions and staff of the Department of External Affairs concerned with the promotion of Canadian culture abroad to the Canada Council. The Canada Council would be renamed the Canada Council for the Arts and for Research in the Social Sciences and Humanities to reflect this expanded function.
I have grave concerns about that latter transfer as well. The Canada Council has never been involved in foreign cultural work on behalf of Canada. It has no personnel who are trained in that particular kind of work. The Department of External Affairs has people posted abroad doing work already. Surely the cultural part of that work has been relatively minor to date. It is surely not taking up a lot of full-time positions in the Department of External Affairs. Yet, the government in its wisdom has decided as an apparent cost saving measure-although it is hard to imagine how this is going to save any money; I expect it will cost more-that it is going to take this jurisdiction away from the Department of External Affairs and create a new international arm, if you like, at the Canada Council. One wonders how many more employees will be required to administer this program now at the Canada Council than are currently engaged in external affairs, where surely it is a very part-time function of most of the officers involved in it.
I am very concerned about this not being a cost-saving measure at all, but in fact one that will cost Canadians
more. This whole scheme was very ill-conceived. The government did not apply its mind to the problem before it brought this bill before the House or before it introduced the budget. I am sure it was a last minute thing in an effort to get an impressive list of government agencies that could be folded up. It stuck this particular one on the list because it had nothing else to do and it had to make the list look impressive and long.
We know from the savings that have been announced on the total list that the savings on this particular aspect of it must really be peanuts. If the government were saving money there, it has been spending it elsewhere.
We had a spectacle recently in Kingston. The new minister of state for science came to Kingston on January 22. If he would have told me he was coming, I would have gone to the airport to meet him but he did not let me know. He came to Kingston and announced the Prime Minister's awards for teaching excellence in Kingston. He issued a lot of fancy, very colourful and beautifully printed brochures and $585,000 worth of prizes. They are not actually scholarships, just prizes. They are to be given to deserving teachers across Canada who assist their students with quality education in science and mathematics.
It is a fine program, but you have to wonder. The government is saying we have to save money by bunching these agencies together and forcing them to do things together when in fact they should be separately represented and are doing a perfectly adequate job at a relatively modest cost now. How did it find the money in the year of an election to come up with $585,000 worth of prizes?

I suspect we might find in next year's budget, if this group is re-elected, this program cut as a cost saving measure because they could not afford it any more. Yet in an election year they can afford it, a year when they are closing down the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and disbanding some of its activities by forcing it in with the Canada Council and similarly putting works of the Canada Council at risk. I also note that this particular $585,000 prize program, the Prime Minister's teachers' awards for excellence, comes at a time when the department of science as I understand it has recently had cuts. The hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell no doubt is aware of this. I read in the paper recently that 180 jobs were cut in that department the other day. Why was that? A shortage of money. Yet the government managed to find $500,000 for this program, plus the unaccounted for costs of administration. We have not heard about those.
At a time when the government is preaching restraint to its employees, firing off right, left and centre saying it has too many employees, their jobs are redundant and it does not need them any longer, it is embarking on new prize givings for Canadians all in the name of the Prime Minister and clearly designed to be handed out in the course of an election campaign.
These changes in this law are opposed by the scientific community in Canada. I have a letter from the Social Science Federation of Canada signed by their executive director. I would welcome his remarks in the course of the debate on this bill.
He must have concerns about this bill and the fact that these agencies which have functioned perfectly well before are being lumped together. Given the government's record of funding cuts, of failure to support the scientific community in Canada, which we have seen repeatedly in the reductions that the government has introduced in this budget particularly, one can only worry about the future of the social sciences in this country.
I am proud to say that I was a graduate in the social sciences. I studied political science and economics. I enjoyed the experience very much. I do not say that it was great preparation for being a member of this House but it certainly did me no harm and brought me into contact with this institution.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to my hon. friend as I did in the earlier part of the session when he began his speech.
I must say his logic fails me in these times when the public and even his own leader is calling for more efficient use of taxpayer resources. It is not just a matter of cost cutting, though cost cutting is extremely important. The issue involved here is service to the public. The world changes and as the world changes, institutions of government must change in order to respond.
I quote from his leader's speech the other day when at the University of Ottawa he said: "Our challenge today is to adapt the role of government to a new world". That is what this government has been doing in a variety of ways. I am pleased to see that the Liberal Party is starting to discover some of the wisdom of the policies of this government by following suit in a number of the policy pronoucements they have been taking.
However, that is not the purpose of this discussion. My hon. friend speaks with specific reference to the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and the other funding agencies. I have been a great supporter of the work of these agencies. The Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council had the good wisdom some years ago to award me a doctoral fellowship. Naturally I have a great appreciation for its judgment and the quality of its work.
It is important this work continue. It is important that the support of research both at the graduate level and at the post-doctoral level be carried out and be supported. Whether that necessitates the maintenance of three separate bureaucracies is a different question.
What is before this House is not the value and the importance of that work. It is not the rigor with which those applications are screened by experts in the field on the basis of peer review as they are. That is the basis upon which those decisions are made.
My hon. friend knows perfectly well that people sometimes make mischief with decisions made by granting agencies by pointing out that a grant was made to this person to study this or that. They try to tag the government when in fact, peer review is the only proper basis. That is the basis upon which it will be done in the future.
What is being done here is an improvement of the system. It makes the process work more efficiently for the benefit both of the clients of the system but also for the modest benefit of the taxpayer as well.
Perhaps my friend would like to reflect upon those no doubt profound remarks and offer his observations.

Mr. Speaker, I would be delighted to reflect on what the hon. member said. I would love to believe what he said but he has not cited a tittle of evidence in support of the fact that this is going to save the Canadian taxpayers a single cent.

The Social Science and Humanities Research Council functions very well. It is one of three granting councils in Canada. The three granting councils act in a similar fashion. It is not a merger of the three granting councils that is being proposed in this bill. It is moving one of them into the Canada Council which does a different kind of function, albeit similar, but is not the same. It grants exclusively to the arts.
The Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council, NSERC and the MRC are the granting councils for three academic disciplines. They normally act in roughly the same way in terms of peer review and so on.
February 1, 1993

That is not what is proposed to be changed in this bill. What the government is doing is taking one of those three academic granting councils and putting it in with an arts granting council and saying that the two can work together now. It does not make sense. If there were some move to put the three granting councils under one roof, there might be some justification for it and there might be some saving to taxpayers. I do not know.
There certainly is not a saving by merging these functions and by transferring the external affairs functions, which I noticed my hon. friend blithely skipped over. A copy was sent to me from the vice-principal of health services at Queen's University, Dr. Duncan Sinclair. I would like to read part of the letter just to indicate the degree of dissatisfaction with the government's policy. It states:

Hidden away in Mr. Mazankowski's economic statement of December 4 was announcement of your government's decision to renege on your previous very far-sighted commitment to provide increases to the federal granting councils of 4 per cent in funding for each of the next four years. When this commitment was made, many of us commended you and your colleagues for having the foresight to invest in the nation's future even at a time of severe financial constraint. We were all aware that increases of 4% would not go far to undo the many years of relative neglect of investment in research and development in Canada but we agreed then it was a start, and a good one given the state of our economy.
That this decision has been reversed is dismaying at the least and unconscionable at the worst. speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS) ACT 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to participate in this debate. I am going to refresh the House's memory as to why this legislation has been brought forward and place it in context as well.
It is interesting to note that today we have well over 400 separate organizations and advisory bodies that comprise the Government of Canada. There are 26 statutory departments, 80 departmental agencies, 56 Crown corporations and over 200 boards, tribunals, councils and other advisory bodies. There are times when one wonders how decisions ever get made in the government with so many agencies, bodies and individuals involved in the making of them.
If the government is going to meet the needs of the people it has to move with the times. Sometimes there is a sentiment, and I sense this sentiment as prevailing on the other side of the House, that once something is created it is created in perpetuity whether it has a purpose to exist or not. That is not the philosophy which prevails on this side of the House. We see the government's role as providing service to Canadians in response to needs which have been identified. Some of those needs last for many years and others are short in their duration.
The purpose of this bill as a budgetary measure is part of the process of streamlining government. It is not just for the cost savings although obviously they are a very important factor. It is important to note that this streamlining exercise which has been going on and was manifested in Bill C-63 and indicated in the budget of the Minister of Finance in March 1992 when he announced the winding down or closure of 47 agencies, still leaves over 400 of these agencies.
This streamlining process is to take place not only for the purpose of saving money, although that is important. Saving money and efficiently using tax dollars is of importance to taxpayers. It is important to me as a taxpayer because I do not want to see the government waste my tax dollars. I want to see the most effective and efficient use made of them. There is also the matter of service to the public. How can government best provide the services? How can government best respond to the individual needs of the taxpayers and the citizens of the country? That is what this exercise is all about as well.
It is interesting to note that we have had such a proliferation of government in this country that we now have to have meetings of interdepartmental groups to decide things simply because so many different departments are involved in the same decision. I understand for example that 11 federal government agencies or departments were involved in a simple exercise like planning the Canada Day celebrations last year.
February 1, 1993

Today there are four different federal government departments involved in the inspection of food: National Health and Welfare; Agriculture Canada; Fisheries and Oceans; and Consumer and Corporate Affairs. Does this sort of duplication and overlap make sense?
I guess from time to time it is incumbent upon the government as part of the process of serving the Canadian people to take a look at the machinery and structure of government that exists and see if there are ways to reconstitute things so it can more effectively serve the Canadian people. That is really what it is all about.
It is reasonable to ask the question from time to time: Does the purpose for which this agency or board was established still exist? If it does not then obviously it is time to get rid of it. Or the question could be as to whether there is a better way to do it. Or if other agencies and departments have been developed meaning there is some sort of overlap, then by collapsing them together the service could more efficiently be provided.
We are talking about service to Canadians along with decision making and cutting down on the red tape and bureaucracy by which things happen. That is really what this exercise of which Bill C-93 is a part is very important.
Reference has been made in this debate to the privatization program of this government. Indeed, this bill is sponsored by the Minister of State for Finance and Privatization. Privatization is a process by which the taxpayers are relieved of costs with which they are burdened.
I am pleased to say that this government during eight and a half years in office has removed 90,000 people from its payroll. I hasten to add that most of those people are still employed but they are employed in the private sector. They are no longer the burden of the taxpayer and so it should be. The people of Canada are looking to government to streamline itself to provide services in a most efficient way and with whatever possible benefits there can be for the taxpayer.
Government Orders
It is appropriate to look at each agency and ask the question: Does the need still exist? Is there a public policy objective and can that public policy objective be more effectively served through the private sector? If it can be provided through the private sector then clearly there is no reason for the government to be involved. That is the philosophy on this side of the House. I suspect that does not necessarily apply to my colleagues opposite who seem to think the government should have its nose in everybody's business from time to time.
Our view is that the government should be motivated by the question of how best it can serve the public and how best it can provide a good deal for the taxpayer. That really is what part of the present bill is all about.
On the subject of cost savings it is important to make a point and I have heard some members in this debate discuss how much money would be saved. I think the amount of money to be saved in this bill is relatively modest. However, over time if we improve the efficiency of the government and services to the Canadian people, that in itself is an important thing. Clearly, there will be some modest savings effected as a result of this piece of legislation and that obviously is very important.
I think we should be looking even further. Ihke for example the matter of decentralization of government. Perhaps my perspective is somewhat impacted by the fact that I live in Nova Scotia and not in central Canada or in Ottawa.
Why is it that the Government of Canada is so centralized in Ottawa? What is more ridiculous than the idea of the Department of Fisheries and Oceans being headquartered here in Ottawa? Why do we have a massive bureaucracy of people, working very hard granted, involved in fisheries right here in Ottawa where the only fish in town are at the Dominion stores? Why is the department of fisheries not operated out of the regions, out of Nova Scotia or Atlantic Canada with another segment of the department in British Columbia where people really have a sense of what the fishery is all about? These are questions that need to be asked. Do we need these great bureaucracies?

February 1, 1993
Government Orders
I strongly and openly recommend to the Minister of Finance in his review of government boards, agencies and departments that he take a serious look at the whole business of whether the entire Government of Canada has to be in Ottawa.
After all, not all Canadians are in Ottawa. What is wrong with the Government of Canada performing some of its central decision making services in Nova Scotia, Saskatchewan, Newfoundland or British Columbia? Is there anything wrong with that?
I certainly do not think so. I do not think so at all. I think we need to do more reviewing of these agencies of government and the tremendous bureaucracies that seem to have developed. They take on an existence of their own which may or may not have anything to do with why they were established in the first place.
This is important. I would ask all members of this House to recognize in this bill a very important step forward in looking at government and at how government can best serve the people of Canada. That is what this streamlining process is all about. It is about service to Canadians and it is about decision making.
I am sure hon. members like myself frequently get calls from constituents about granting processes or decisions. When you go to get copies of the forms that are there for approving things, it is amazing. Some require seven, eight and nine signatures before a decision can be made. I wonder why that is so. Why not hire a competent person who knows what they are doing and let them make the decision?
Again, I use the example of the fisheries. Why are individual licensing decisions made here in Ottawa? Why are they not made by the very excellent fisheries and oceans staff in Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, in the gulf and so on? The point I am making is that we need more streamlining of government and this bill represents a very important step in the right direction.
Any suggestion that my remarks are critical of any individuals who work for the Government of Canada would not be appropriate. My experience is that Canada benefits from an extremely dedicated Public Service. We have a competent Public Service with people who do what we in this House try to do, namely serve the Canadian people as well as they can.
The question is how can we do it in order to provide the best service? All of these various structures of government exist for one purpose only, to serve the Canadian people. That applies to us and to all departments and agencies. Therefore, the reviewing of these structures of government, the decision that was taken and the thrust implied in the budget of the minister last year, is an extremely important one. It is beneficial for Canadians.
I might say, unlike my hon. friend who spoke just prior to me and who has a large university in his constituency, that I have not had a lot of people phoning me and saying that they disagree with this legislation. It is quite the contrary. I remember when the budget came down that I received a number of comments from people saying: Delighted to see that you are thinning government a little bit. Some have even gone so far as to suggest to me that I should thin down myself a little bit, and I must say that is certainly an aspiration that I have. The process of thinning and streamlining government is one that is indeed supported by the public.
Most people wonder why we are debating this at all. After all, this is a budget implementation measure. The principle of doing what this bill is here to do has already been approved by this House and, I might say, has been significantly endorsed by people from coast to coast.
This debate in a way, while it is legally necessary, is really an after the fact debate. This House and the Canadian people spoke on this measure when they passed the budget. Nevertheless, the bill is before us. I think it is very consistent with where the Canadian public wants to see government restructure in this country. I heartily commend the government for bringing forth this measure and encourage all members to give it their support.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to comment on what was said by the Conservative member for South Shore, in Nova Scotia. I saw him make a big song and dance about the need for further decentralizing the Public Service so that people in his riding would have a place to find work besides the Dominion stores. I do not know exactly how long he has been a member of the House, but I do know he has been here for at least four and a half years.
February 1, 1993

The hon. member may have been here since 1984 but, if he has, he certainly is not doing his homework because he ought to know that decentralization of the Public Service has been taking place since 1972. If he bothered to make inquiries he would receive a little brochure from the Public Service explaining that there is a quota system for public servants across Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I rise in opposition to the bill before us today, Bill C-93, in particular that section pertaining to the abolition of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and the international cultural programs.
As the House knows, Bill C-93 has various sections in it. It rises from the budget of February of last year and my colleagues from my party will have some things to say on some of the changes. We have no trouble at all with some parts. My comments will be restricted mainly to the part that sees the Canada Council taking over the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and the international cultural programs.
I have listened to government members try to justify this. They spoke in large generalities of abolishing and
Government Orders
therefore came to the conclusion that this would save money. They said by bringing the function of the Canada Council with the functions of SSHRC and the international cultural programs together, this was automatically going to save money. One hon. government member did admit that the money to be saved was quite insignificant.
We really do not know if money is going to be saved. You can come to that type of conclusion by bringing something together so therefore you are going to save money but that is not necessarily the case.
I have heard other hon. government members make these great statements on how they have reduced the Public Service and how much money they have saved. Of course they never mention the increase in the number of consultants they have had to hire. They never mention the increased costs of going through consulting companies. When you balance the two together you come to the conclusion that not much money has been saved.
What happens of course is that ordinaiy workers in the Public Service have less protection because now many of them are working as employees in private consulting companies quite often doing the same job they were doing before but they do not have the type of protection and the type of social benefits they would formerly have.
The government is still paying the same amount of money but it is now paying that amount of money to the heads of some of the private firms who are now collecting some of that money as profits. It is not really much of a cost saving. What is the cost saving on this measure that is part of Bill C-93?
We have to examine how much money is to be saved in dollars and cents. We must compare the effectiveness of this new organization to the effectiveness of the existing arrangement and then determine the cost.
I am suggesting that what we must do is examine whatever potential savings there might be and examine the effectiveness of the delivery of programs to determine whether any of these possible savings are made at the expense of lower delivery of service to the clientele. Then we can see what the bottom line is and determine whether money will indeed be saved and whether the effectiveness of the programs will be reduced.

February 1, 1993
Government Orders
One of the things that is really discouraging is the method by which the government undertook to implement these changes. There was no consultation. I understand that even the minister responsible was totally unprepared for this change. It was a change that was thrown in at the very last minute.
I understand that one of the ministers was going to address some of the social scientists. When he heard the budget it was the first time that he was aware that SSHRC was to be abolished. Of course, the minister cancelled his appointment to talk to the social scientists because he did not want to meet with them and have to justify what the government had done. Despite the fact that he was the minister in charge of SSHRC he did not even know about the changes that were coming.
So much for consultation, even within the government. It is no wonder that we have a very inefficient and ineffective government because even among the cabinet level they do not communicate with each other, let alone between departments.
We are also quite unhappy with things in the act itself. We do not accept that SSHRC should be folded into the Canada Council. We are also unhappy with what happens after that. We are not happy at all with the board and the way in which this new organization is to be governed.
We are not happy with the lack of assurance in the bill itself that the money that will go for research for the social sciences and humanities will come out of a research envelope. Verbal assurances have been given to SSHRC that for the next number of years its funding will come from the research envelope. They will not be in competition with the Canada Council for money that will go to culture in this country. However, there is no assurance or backup in the bill itself.
I have spoken to social scientists. They are quite concerned and I do not blame them. This government has said many things. The Prime Minister has said many things. He has made many promises and statements. However when the actual reality comes into play, when we actually see what the government does, it is quite the opposite.
I would not want to go so far in this House as to suggest that the government lies but I would not trust it. I do not blame the members of the social sciences community for not trusting this government when it comes to any verbal commitment as to what the sources of funding would be.
Why is it important to the social sciences that they not be forgotten and confused with the Canada Council? It is not that they have any objection or fights with the Canada Council. There are some similarities, particularly when we deal with the humanities and the Canada Council. That is the reason that originally the Canada Council and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council were one. A decision was made in 1978 to separate the two after a long time of consultation and discussion within the academic and cultural communities. There were some very valid reasons for that decision.
One of the major reasons, which I hope this government might understand, is that the social sciences and the humanities conduct research into some extremely important elements of our society. That role is different from what the Canada Council does and funds.
We are living in a day and age of very rapid social change. Never in the history of the human race has there been such a rate of change. It is a rate of change that continues to accelerate. Think of the difference between now, in 1993, and 1983 or 1973, only 10, 20 years ago. The social changes and the economic changes have been horrendous, and not just in our North American and Canadian society but on a global level. We know that these changes are going to continue to accelerate.
The question that we have to ask as a society is: Do we continually react to these changes or do we try to anticipate, try to understand, try to predict and try to do things so that we can go through these changes with the least amount of human harm? An intelligent society wants to understand the forces that are changing it. It wants to understand them so that it can take measures that will allow it to survive those changes with the least amount of human hardship and harm, so that it can go through those changes and be better able to profit from the positive side of those changes.

Just in terms of economics the social sciences are involved in research on physical problems, monetary policy, urban development, productivity, economic and strategic planning, managing for global competitiveness, and science and technological innovation policy. They are also doing research on family violence, an aging population, racism, sexism, youth and unemployment. They are doing important research that affects our native people and aboriginal people. It is important research and essential research.
If we are going to go through the end of this century and into the next century and the next millennium we need this research.
I know that the minister in charge of privatization and his colleagues in the Conservative government consider themselves to be tough macho characters. They consider all this social science research stuff to be woolly, soft, marshmallow type stuff. They feel that we really do not need it and that it is a waste of government money. Quite often the research that is done contradicts the government's policies. The government members are tough macho people and they figure that people will be able to toughen things out and toughen out the economic and social changes in our world. I believe many of them secretly believe that all this social science stuff is pinko stuff that is not really needed. I suspect that many government members in their hearts would like to see all of the social sciences and humanities abolished.

persuade Canadians to give it a third mandate. This is part of the plan.

speechtext:
My friend said that is right. I am glad that he agrees with me. I know he was not saying what I was saying was correct. That is what he was agreeing to. Absolutely. I know that. He knows it will not save any real money. He knows it will not increase effectiveness but he knows what it is trying to do.
He was probably at that strategy table trying to determine what it was going to do to persuade Canadians to say yes, it is okay. Canadians are not going to say yes, it is okay. It wants to try to persuade Canadians that something is in fact being done when it is not being done.
Let us look at the bill. A number of colleagues have talked about the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council. It is an important part. I shall stress that part, but at the same time I will say that it deals with a number of other features.
It is called the budget implementation, the Government Organization Act, 1992. That is rather impressive, is it not, Government Organization. It talks about the Agricultural Products Board. Some of my colleagues have addressed that, so I will not go into any detail.

February 1, 1993
Government Orders
Therein lies one of the traps. Canadians have never heard about those things before. As one of my colleagues pointed out, one of them has not been sitting for 16 years. Probably a few others have been dead for some time too.
My colleagues want to abolish something that is already dead. What a functional piece of legislation this is. Therein lies one of the traps that they are trying to set. They come out with these rather impressive titles and Canadians, they hope, will be persuaded that something meaningful is being done. Somehow they hope that they can change those opinion polls around.
Let me deal with perhaps the most significant part of the bill for many, many Canadians. It is the clauses that would wind up the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and transfer its functions and staff to the Canada Council. That is bothering most Canadians and is one of the aspects of this bill that this government will live to regret.
There is another feature that I think the government has forgotten. It has forgotten that this particular council is a grant-giving body which administers funds for research and scholarship. It was created in 1977 and it has worked well ever since.
The second part troubling Canadians is that the Department of External Affairs has a staff of approximately 25 people working for the International Cultural and Academic Relations Program. It forecasts a budget for this program of $27 million. The Canada Council, which was created in 1957, offers grants and services to artists and art organizations. It has a staff of 248.
The govemement is going to put all that together. It has not shown us at all where money will be saved, whether or not there will be jobs lost and I hope that there are not, or whether or not there will be money saved. It has not done anything. It takes these organizations which many people know little about and tries to suggest that something meaningful will be done. All it is, in the final analysis, is the creation of perception.
Let us look at what the academic community has said about these.

I have in front of me a press release dated November 30, 1992, just a few months ago. It says: "Funding of social science research threatened".

Funding for the social sciences research is threatened. That is what these people think about it.
"Merger legislation threatens eclipse of humanities research". That is what is being said. There is a lot more. Funding for social sciences research is threatened and may not be able to be continued, which is the gist of this argument, at the level or quality that has been so in the past.
I have another communique from the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada. I will read the headline: "Abolition of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council is turning back the clock". It goes on to say that this particular association has concerns about this council's programs being taken over by the Canada Council. It makes several important points.
This same organization says that the transfer of the International Academic Relations Program from External Affairs to Canada Council could also be problematic. It goes on to point out that the importance of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council to Canada's over-all research effort is one of paramount importance. It describes the history of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council in Canada. I would urge colleagues to read this because it has some excellent notes with which they may not be familiar.
In another communique from the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada it says that the merger of these academic relations and cultural programs is neither necessary nor desirable. It proposes a series of amendments that would shift the emphasis in an appropriate direction.
However I am sure the government has not taken the time to look at this. It does not want to listen to Canadians. We know that because if it had been listening to Canadians it would have put a halt to this. It would have consulted the people of Canada who are those most directly affected.
February 1, 1993



Mr. Speaker, you know very well that these people have a better idea of the impact of this bill on then-organizations and on what these organizations do for Canadians.

Here is another communique from the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada with respect to the mini budget.

This mini budget has left a bitter taste with the universities. Why? Because the universities have been betrayed. That is why. They have been betrayed.
Here is another communique, this time from the Social Science Federation of Canada: "The government is defying its commitments to fund social sciences". In what way is the government defying its commitments?

The government, subsequent to or roughly at the same time as part of its strategy, decided to merge those.

Mr. Speaker, you know that as well as I do. [English]
It knew there would be a problem because it did not consult, it did not make sense and it had not thought it out. The government said: "Aha". It held out a carrot. "There will be a 4 per cent increase in research and development funding". However, a few months later, after a great announcement about that 4 per cent increase over four years, what did the government do? It reneged on that.
If one can renege on that-supposedly you are in a worse financial position than you thought you were when you made the announcement-then one admits two things. First, one did not do one's financial predictions particularly well. It was not done well at all.

Most people would agree with me that when I promise something publicly and then come back later saying
Government Orders
"Well, listen, I did not fully realize the budget constraints, et cetera", that does not look good and that is not right at all. Something comes to mind, which I think would be almost too awful to say.

The people will not forget that a promise was made and that the promise was not carried out. It would not be so bad if it was the first time but it is not the first time.
I have another communique from the Canadian Federation for the Humanities: "A promise is a promise or is it?" I have another communique: "Bitter surprises for universities in mini budget".
Let us remember this. It is so critically important. I know that my colleagues will agree with me on this point even if they might disagree or question the others. Our greatest challenges in this country are really the social problems of the nation. In fact they may be the greatest challenges of this planet.
Say one stops to think for a moment to say: "What are the difficulties that this country is experiencing?" One would talk about our poor. There are different statistics but many people would agree that there are almost five million. It depends upon how one defines poverty and I understand that. However the majority of them are women and one million are children.
One would also recognize that there are more than 1.6 million unemployed Canadians in this country today. Most of them want a job and want to work but there are no jobs. This is the latest figure I have been using. I am told it is too low and I am sorry that it is too low, but there are over 2.2 million Canadians who are receiving social assistance. Apparently that is crowding 3 million people. The food banks at one time were using the figure of 2 million people to feed. It is now in excess of that.
Those are the challenges that are facing Canadians and those are the challenges that are facing this government as it enters this new session. The government is now trying to give the impression of doing something by taking some organizations that never meet and suggesting that if it takes them out it is going to save money and it is going to bring greater government effectiveness.
Let me go on to some additional social challenges.

February 1, 1993
Government Orders

Almost every day we talk about the problems of abuse. Whether it is abuse of the elderly, children, people one is living with, too often of wives, these are challenges for our society. We talk about this abuse because we recognize that it must not be tolerated in this society.
When I talk about the unemployment rate, about people receiving welfare, about men, women and children who will be fed by food banks, about abuse, be it abuse of seniors, women or children, who are the people who could enlighten us and possibly provide solutions?

Of course, it is the people who are called social scientists, broadly defined, who could bring us some answers to those questions. They are the people who could somehow give us a new sense of direction and possible new solutions so that all of us who are committed to ridding society of those ills could make some progress toward that.
It is important to look at this action on the part of government, which I said was for purely political reasons. One has to understand what has been happening to the total culture of education.
There will be $10 billion less transferred for education from 1986 to 1995 in about a decade. There will be fewer dollars if one adjusts for inflation, and the need out there for training and retraining is increasing.
With respect to research and development, the government made a promise to double its investments and match Japan, U.S., Germany, France and other countries. What has happened? We have slipped even further.
I have not even talked about student debt or the astronomical increases in tuition fees and incidental fees in universities. I could go on but we have to look at the merger in this context. I conclude by asking the government to consider this proposal, to stop proceeding with this bill and consult. When it has consulted and if it firmly believes that it is the best decision for our academic community, our students and other Canadians, it can go ahead, but not without consulting and thinking it over.

Mr. Speaker, I must say that the rhetoric of my hon. friend far exceeds his logic.

government must respond to the needs of the people?
