For example, can the long distance heavy trucking burden on our highways not be relieved by such concepts as piggyback services over corridor rail lines? Are there not economic incentives or disincentives that can be designed to redirect freight traffic from the roads to the rails?
These are important questions for Atlantic transportation policy, and in view of current circumstances they deserve serious consideration now.

Mr. Speaker, today marks the beginning of International Development Week in Canada. International Development Week provides Parliament, the government and Canadians with an opportunity to reflect on Canada's long-standing commitment to Third World development.
Development week is a time for all of us to congratulate development NGOs and their thousands of volunteers for their vital and tireless efforts. Non-governmental organizations work as partners with local groups in developing countries. Together they work to improve basic health care, education and training, farming techniques, small business enterprise, and a host of similar projects. NGOs are experienced, efficient and accountable.
The government has indicated that it intends to cut aid to Third World countries in favour of eastern Europe. We agree that eastern Europe needs help, but such help should not come instead of or at the expense of Third World countries or the funding of NGO work in those countries.

February 1, 1993

Mr. Speaker, I would like to clarify several misconceptions going around in the media about the proposed changes to unemployment insurance. There were references to a confrontation between the minister and the Quebec caucus, even a revolt. Such allegations are unfounded.
Of course it is only normal that we question the minister on behalf of our constituents, which we did and continue to do in a spirit of close collaboration and mutual understanding.
We are all in agreement on the principle of the measures announced by the Minister of Finance in his economic statement of December 2,1992 and reports are to the effect that the vast majority of Canadians and Quebecers are also in agreement.
However, my colleagues and I want to make sure that these measures will not be unfairly implemented. The members on this side of the House are faithful to the same basic principles of fairness, economy and, above all, justice.

Mr. Speaker, during the last two months Montrealers have been victims of right wing violence and vandalism.
In December a church used by Haitian Quebecers and a mosque were set on fire, and youths attacked and killed a man they believed to be gay. On January 2 seven synagogues were desecrated with swastikas and hate slogans. On January 27 anti-Semitic symbols were spray-painted on a synagogue, a community centre, four cars and two homes. Just yesterday two school buses were spray-painted with anti-Jewish slogans and swastikas.
There is troubling evidence that these are not isolated incidents. New groups are emerging in Canada. Students are being recruited in our schools and modern technologies are being used to propagate hatred. For these reasons B'Nai Brith has called for a royal commission on racism.
I urge the Minister of Justice to meet with B'Nai Brith, to review its recommendations, and to take action to demonstrate that racism will not be tolerated in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, citizens in my riding and across Canada are deeply horrified at the Nazi-like atrocities occurring in Bosnia-Hercegovina and other parts of the former Yugoslavia. The United Nations is condoning ethnic cleansing by its proposals which allow territory seized by force to be retained.
I urge the Secretary of State for External Affairs to demand that the United Nations impose a peace plan which respects the territory of Bosnia-Hercegovina and the property rights of former residents, and which imposes a war crimes tribunal that will punish these barbaric acts.
The world should not stand by and watch.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the government's cancelling of the inactive groundfish licensing is a reversal of a 10-year old policy known as the bona fide licensing policy.
This licensing policy gave priority to full-time fishermen to hold multiple licences and retain them even if they were not used. This multiple licensing policy allowed fishermen to play a direct role in resource conservation.
The fact that fishermen have not used these licences for two years means that they have helped to conserve the stocks. Yet the administration in Ottawa has chosen to penalize them.
I believe that the Maritime Fishermen's Union, the Prince Edward Island Fishermen's Association and the Eastern Fishermen's Federation are correct in challenging the minister and his groundfish management plan for 1993.
The onus of proof should be on the Government of Canada, not on inshore fishermen, as to whether the new policy of eliminating licences will conserve stocks. The Government of Canada must be condemned for the abrupt and arbitrary fashion in which the long-standing policy was reversed thereby hurting inshore fishermen.
February 1, 1993

Mr. Speaker, citizens living in a village within my constituency are gathering today in a place they would much rather not be. The people of St. Eustache, Manitoba, are burying their dead.
Maurice and Sherri-Lee Paul were stalked and murdered last week while in the confines of their own home. St. Eustache is a quiet small village. Maurice and Sherri-Lee were active, community minded parents of three children. They were well known and liked in St. Eustache. Like so many others they did not deserve to die.
It is time we put some teeth in the laws of this land. The killer of Sherri-Lee and Maurice had a restraining order prohibiting contact with the family. The Pauls sought refuge in the law, in the system. TTie system let them down.
This House must enact legislation now so that other communities will not be put through what St. Eustache is suffering today.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister said in 1987:
Our highest priority is to have a trade agreement that ends the threat to Canadian industry from U.S. protectionists who harass and restrict our exports through the misuse of trade remedy laws.
The Prime Minister failed in achieving this highest priority and trade harassment continues in steel, pork and softwood lumber.
With the failure of free trade and the rejection of a sectoral trade agreement by the United States, where does that leave Canadian steelworkers whose work force has been decimated with 12,000 lay-offs in four years?
The trade minister is now suggesting, believe it or not, a blue ribbon commission to study the industry and make recommendations to both governments, but as of this morning there has been no formal proposal to the U.S. government.
As to the dispute panel and its decisions, it would appear that if the U.S.A. wins a ruling it is commonplace and quite acceptable, whereas if Canada wins there has been an extraordinary mistake and the ruling is challenged.
May I suggest to the Prime Minister that the steel trade be upper-

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order, please.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this past weekend the town of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, was struck with yet another sea disaster with the loss of the Cape Aspy, some 67 miles off Cape Sable Island. Although we are grateful that 11 crew members survived, Captain Albert Eisner and 4 others perished.
I wish to commend the efforts of the crews of the vessels and aircraft that came to the rescue, together with those involved in the search and rescue effort.
On the best of summer days the North Atlantic can be a killer. During a winter storm with high seas and ice build-up it is positively terrifying. Any way we cut it, fishing is a tough and at times perilous way to make a living.
I wish to pay tribute to the men and families who generation after generation have prosecuted Canada's oldest industry. I am sure all members join with me in expressing our sympathy to the families and friends of the men lost at sea this weekend.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Conservative government is now clinging desperately to power, afraid to give the public the opportunity to throw them from office.
In 1984 a colleague of hon. members opposite made the following speech: "After four years Canadians are entitled to have their say about the government. After four years Canada is entitled to a general election. For all practical purposes the government's term has come to an end. Only political cowardice or contempt for the democratic process could explain why after four years in power the government refuses to announce a general election. It has to if it has any respect for democracy".

February 1, 1993
Oral Questions
Those words came from none other than Senator Lowell Murray, the Prime Minister's confidant and government leader in the other place. The Prime Minister should heed the advice of his friend given so freely and forcefully in 1984.
I hope all hon. members opposite, unless of course they have no respect for democracy, will convey their feelings to their leader and convince him to go to the people now. Goodness knows the people are waiting.
[English)

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the right hon. Prime Minister. The Prime Minister might feel that he is not obliged to give a straight answer to his caucus, to his cabinet colleagues or to the press, but he has an obligation to tell the truth to the Canadian people and clear the air. We would like to have a straight answer. Is the Prime Minister quitting? Yes or no.
I have some difficulty finding that question in order. Perhaps the hon. Leader of the Opposition might try to put his question in another way.
Mr. Speaker, I do not know why the Prime Minister is refusing to reply to this question.
I probably should point out that I did not agree the question was in order.

Mr. Speaker, it is a very serious question because ministers are campaigning instead of working and the bureaucrats do not know where they are going. I would like to know if there will be a change in the role of the Prime Minister in the next few weeks?

Mr. Speaker, given the fact that my hon. friend has been saying for weeks that he could hardly wait to get back to the House to lay out his program for job creation and social advancement in Canada, I find it somewhat interesting he would waste questions. He indicated that he could hardly wait to get to the House to ask questions
and advance his alternatives on GST, free trade and all those other matters.
Inasmuch as he is asking this question and he persists in it, perhaps I could just tell him this. In the 10 years as leader of my party, I had the privilege of doing pretty well against a Liberal leader in 1984. Then in 1988 we did pretty well again. With a leader like this, my expectation is that the triple crown is just around the comer.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is very easy. If we really want the country to feel good then do not chicken out. Call the election right away. Again the government has proposed we should have a free trade agreement with the United States.
In spite of the free trade agreement this government has not been able to convince the American administration to establish dumping and tariff rules that will work. So last week the United States treated Canada exactly the same way it treats any other country.
Will the Prime Minister or the minister explain to the nation why the Americans do not want to respect the so-called free trade agreement with Canada?

Mr. Speaker, I have to conclude that my hon. friend is suggesting we ought not to have a free trade agreement with the United States in which case we would not have available to us the appeal procedure to a binational-
What a joke.

My hon. friends say what a joke. There have been eight such instances under the free trade agreement and we have won eight out of eight. That is not a joke. That is a reality.
Canada has increased its exports to the United States in steel. Steel exports are up by 41 per cent. Even though we are going through difficult times, of the 19 countries hit by this tariff Canada is the only one capable of appealing to a binational panel composed of an equal number of Canadians and Americans. We have won those cases in the past and we are going to win again. If the Leader of the Opposition had his way there would be no such panel and Canadians would be the losers.
February 1, 1993

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let the Prime Minister explain that to the workers at Sidbec in Quebec and the workers in Sault Ste Marie and Hamilton, hundreds of whom are losing their jobs each month.
Why does the Prime Minister not admit that they made a mistake by failing to negotiate subsidy rules that would be binding on both countries? That is the problem we have today. The Americans apply their own laws, but we should have rules that are binding on both countries.

Mr. Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition will have to make up his mind. Does he or does he not support the free trade agreement? Does he or does he not support the GST? Does he or does he not support this government's policies?
As far as free trade is concerned, I may point out that compared with 1988-before the free trade agreement came into force-our annual exports of goods to the United States have increased by $17 billion. In November the value of our exports of machinery and equipment rose 24 per cent over the previous year. The value of our exports of consumer goods has increased 24.8 per cent and, listen to this, the value of exports of automobile products increased 11.4 per cent over the previous year.
The free trade agreement is a great success and without it Canada would now be at a distinct disadvantage. At a time when every single country in the world would like to have this kind of agreement with the United States, we have one.

Mr. Speaker, the fact is that during the three years since this so-called free trade agreement came along, the Canadian steel industry has lost $1 billion in investment. In my own riding and the Hamilton area alone more than 10,000 workers are unemployed.
How can the Prime Minister praise the benefits of this agreement, when last week's steel decision was a travesty of the spirit of free trade?
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member said that problems in the steel industry are all the result of problems with the free trade agreement with the United States. There are many problems throughout the world in this industry. The problems experienced by the Canadian industry with its cost reduction of $100 per tonne are not due to the free trade agreement. The problem lies with the industry in Canada. It is both a management and a labour problem.
That is the problem we have to deal with and my department has already started discussions with the unions and management. It is not a problem with the free trade agreement.

Mr. Speaker, that answer is an absolute disgrace for the minister.
When he suggested there is not a problem with free trade, can he explain why last week despite his claims five years ago that the free trade agreement was going to be great for steel the Americans slapped unfair tariffs against Stelco and Algoma and other Canadian companies? That is not a problem of Canadian management. It is not a problem of Canadian workers. It is a problem of the failure of this government to define what constitutes an unfair subsidy.
Why is the minister blaming Canadian workers and the Canadian steel industry for his own failures and the failure of his government in the free trade negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what is a disgrace is the way that my hon. friend twists the facts and says that the problem is with the free trade agreement with the United States. She knows full well that this is a world-wide problem.
The Canadian industry had not been affected prior to last week by the anti-dumping duties by the Americans. For her to suggest that the problems the industry has suffered over the last three years are the result of the free trade agreement is a total distortion of the facts.

Oral Questions
I did say there was a margin of cost advantage between the Canadian and U.S. industry of $100 a tonne 10 years ago. That has dissipated, not by the free trade agreement but by problems within the industry, some of which can be laid at the doorstep of the companies themselves. That is the problem we are trying to address now.

Mr. Speaker, while the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister wish to debate the employment of one person, I would like to talk about the unemployment of millions in this country.
When the Prime Minister was first elected and was responding to results of the Liberal recession he said: "Unemployment is morally offensive and there is a moral imperative to bring unemployment down".
Since this House rose in December we have seen 400 high-tech jobs lost in Ottawa, 1,450 jobs lost in Oshawa,
10,000	in Canadian railways, 1,200 at Woodward stores, and so on.
We hear that things are improving, but we have to ask one question and one question only. Where are the jobs? How can the Prime Minister justify his policies which have led to what he has said is morally wrong and that is higher unemployment in this country?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend asks where the jobs are.
She indeed raises a serious matter, unlike the Leader of the Opposition. The matter of Canadian employment is a high priority. Canadian unemployment is unfortunately too high.
There has been employment growth in seven of the last eight months with 57,000 new jobs created in December alone. This was the most-
Where?

Where? In Canada. Across Canada there were 57,000 new jobs. My hon. friend should be encouraged as well by the fact that I take the time to answer seriously because it is an important question.
Inflation is down and was annualized at its lowest rate in 30 years. Interest rates in 1992 were annualized at their lowest in 20 years in Canada. The Conference Board indicated this morning that Canada will lead the
G-7 countries in economic growth this year. This combination will allow us to lower the unemployment rate in a durable and ongoing way, not with fly-by-night job creation projects, but in an important, thoughtful and durable way.

Mr. Speaker, the problem is that this government is not launching an attack on unemployment but on the unemployed. The proposed changes to the unemployment insurance system are so abusive and so cruel, especially for women, non-union workers and people who work under hazardous conditions, that the government does not even have the support of all its members.
Will the Prime Minister withdraw his policy on changes to the unemployment insurance system?

Mr. Speaker, we are of course prepared to listen to what all members of this House, including the Leader of the New Democratic Party have to say about any bill.
With respect to unemployment insurance, if she has any suggestions for saving the $600 million we need to reduce the deficit while being fair to workers, I would be delighted to hear them.
However, we are talking about a proposal which-
It's a cruel measure.

The member of the New Democratic Party says it is cruel. In France, the socialist government went ahead with a measure that is practically identical. It cannot be all that cruel in the eyes of international socialism. Of course we will listen carefully to any interesting ideas coming from the opposition.

Mr. Speaker, we have a very simple suggestion. The government should attack unemployment and not the unemployed. The changes it proposes attack the unemployed.
Given the lay-offs we have seen just since December 12 when this House rose, the proposed lay-offs in the railway industry, the devastation across this country in every sector, the large farm rally we saw in Saskatchewan where people were protesting the devastation of rural communities and farms in this country, every policy the government has brought forward has been a failure.
February 1, 1993

I say to the Prime Minister: Do not proceed with changes to UI, do not proceed with the Canada-U.S.-Mexico trade deal, do not bring in another budget, do not do anything except call a federal election. Will the Prime Minister do that?
Mr. Speaker, I considered calling an election, but out of affection for the leader of the NDP I did not.
Oh, oh.
A kinder, gentler Brian Mulroney.

I indicated to my hon. friend that employment rose by 57,000 in December. Employment has risen in seven of the last eight months, a net gain of
134,000	jobs in Canada. Full-time employment increased for a fourth consecutive month, recording a gain of
35,000.	Merchandise exports are up. Unit costs are down 5.2 per cent. Productivity is up by 2.6 per cent and exports are climbing dramatically. That means jobs at home.
I must say this. My hon. friend says cancel the free trade agreement, cancel the GST, cancel our deficit reduction plans, cancel everything. I may disagree with that. I disagree with every single policy she puts forward, but at least she has policies, which is infinitely more than we can say about this bunch.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of employment. His proposed amendments to UI are nothing more than a failed attempt by the minister and his government to distract Parliament and Canadians from the real issues.
The problem is unemployment, not the unemployed. The problem is harassment and arbitrary management, not laziness. The problem is lay-offs and termination, not voluntary quits. Canadians are hard working people. They want to work.
When will this government stop attacking the victims of its economic mismanagement and provide immediate relief and opportunity?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows the December statement was very broad. It encompassed the fiscal deficit and outlined plans to contain it because of the dramatic decline in revenues.
Oral Questions
In the course of containing that slippage, we also provided expenditures toward investing in people, in infrastructure, in training and skills upgrading and particularly in the field of small business. I am encouraged by the response of small business and by the comments of the president of the Canadian Federation of Independent Business who indicated that the December statement was clearly a win-win situation for small business.
The hon. member knows that 80 per cent of new jobs in Canada are created by the small business sector. We believe that the initiatives prescribed in the December statement will go a long way in assisting in the creation of jobs in the small business sector.
I remind the hon. member that the manufacturing sector has grown by 3.5 per cent in the first 11 months of last year thanks to our policies.

Mr. Speaker, thanks to your policies we have 1.6 million Canadians unemployed and 2.2 million Canadians on welfare. The minister is going to stay the course which is absolutely unacceptable.
Canadians need a sound economic plan. Instead of attacking the unemployed, will he attack unemployment by immediately establishing a national apprenticeship training program and a national youth service program to give our young people the skills and opportunities required to get them working again?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know the hon. member is making a pitch for the re-establishment of Katimavik which was not a very successful program.
If the hon. member wants to use statistics, I will certainly use statistics. Total employment in Canada today is 12.24 million and there are 1.8 million who are self-employed. That means there has been an increase in employment of 12 per cent since we have been in office.
Employment has grown, the labour force has grown and continues to grow. The participation rate is higher than that in most G-7 countries. As the labour force grows, job creation becomes that much more of a challenge. The hon. member would be the first to agree, I am sure, that we are going through a period of adjustment and restructuring in order to meet the challenges of a newly emerging economy.

February 1, 1993
Oral Questions
The economic statement I outlined in December speaks to that. I ask the hon. member to re-read it. I am sure he will find there are positive measures in it that will bolster growth and create jobs for the future.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. According to the Conseil regional intersyndical de Montreal, the changes in the unemployment insurance program proposed by the government are like a sledge-hammer being used to crack a nut. It is overkill. How can the Prime Minister justify this excessive and inordinate attack on the Canadian unemployed? Why is it always the unemployed and the needy who are penalized by the administrative incompetence of this government?

Mr. Speaker, we would be delighted if the hon. member would make some concrete suggestions.
Does he think it is unfair and morally indefensible for a government, especially a government that has fiscal problems, like all governments in this country, to decide that if a worker leaves his job voluntarily, without provocation, he should be deprived of the chance to receive unemployment insurance benefits that are paid for by all other workers in Canada?
All legitimate cases are covered: sexual harassment, and so forth. All that is covered by unemployment insurance, as it should be. The fundamental question is this: Does he think it is morally indefensible, in the circumstances, for a government or a Parliament to vote in favour of this kind of legislation? I would like to hear what he has to say about this, as well as any alternatives he has to suggest for streamlining our unemployment insurance system in this country.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very glad to hear the Prime Minister. If anyone in this government knows the construction industry in Quebec, he should, since he was on the Cliche commission and knows very well that Quebec is the only place in the country where the construction industry is governed by a
decree. He is very well aware of the problems. Now I will ask him a very specific question.
With these new changes to unemployment insurance, what happens when an employee working at James Bay has to quit his job because he must go home to deal with family problems? Does the Prime Minister not think that these new measures will penalize the worker, who will not be entitled to unemployment insurance benefits if the employer says he quit his job voluntarily?

Mr. Speaker, it is covered by just cause in section 28.
Now as for sexual harassment-
Answer.

I am answering a question, and the Liberals will not even let me finish my answer. I gave the right answer because it agrees with the facts and reality. But you see, the opposition party did not answer my question. Do they find it morally unacceptable for a government to deprive an employee of unemployment insurance benefits if that person quits his or her job voluntarily, without provocation, for no reason? That is a basic question.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
I am sure the Prime Minister is already aware of the fact that the 13,000 people who attended the farm rally in Saskatoon last Thesday represented the biggest outpouring of support for the farm community in prairie history.
I would also like to remind the Prime Minister that the projected net income for Saskatchewan farmers next year is $4,000, which is less than they would receive on welfare. Many of them are in the hopeless situation of not having enough money to put in next year's crop.
Since the Prime Minister was unable to attend the rally in person, I would like to ask him to tell us today what words of support and encouragement he is prepared to give the farm families of Saskatchewan.
February 1, 1993

speakerposition: Minister of Western Economic Diversification; Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, I attended that meeting and we had a chance to visit at its end. I will say the same thing to the hon. member that I said to him in Saskatoon, we know these are difficult times and we think we understand how difficult it is. At the same time the federal government is providing record amounts of support to producers, not only in Saskatchewan but elsewhere, that have been affected.
If you add up all of the support the federal government has provided over the last six or seven years it has amounted to almost $21,000 per farm in Saskatchewan, which is well above the national average.
We also worked out an agreement a week ago with the province of Saskatchewan to see an additional $170 million go into that province in this calendar year. We have a proposal on the table with Saskatchewan to see an additional $63 million go into that province if we can cost share with the province.
While we recognize the problem and have tried to deal with it, we also know that no matter how much money any government provides, it is not the real answer. The real answer is to get better prices for our product when we sell internationally and the government is very committed to that.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister refused to come to the rally last Tuesday in Saskatoon. He is refusing to answer to the people of Saskatchewan right now.
I want to remind the Prime Minister that last fall he told Premier Romanow and all the people of Saskatchewan that once the results of the harvest were in he would look at providing help if needed. Those 13,000 people last week provided an answer and revealed just how bad things are.
Will the Prime Minister tell the farmers of Saskatchewan and all Canadians exactly how he plans to fulfil the commitment he made to them last fall? The crisis farmers are facing extends far beyond Saskatchewan's borders. If the federal government refuses to take its responsibility seriously, thousands of farmers from across this country will be joining the ranks of the unemployed.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is quite wrong. I did not refuse to attend anything. I had the opportunity to delegate the Minister of Agriculture who himself is a prairie farmer
Oral Questions
and who is committed perhaps as least as much if not more than any member of this House to the well-being of the family farm.
This government brought in-the NDP is asking the question Mr. Speaker. Now they apparently do not want to hear the answer.
This government brought in the GRIP program. This government brought in the NISA program. Both programs are greatly admired by Saskatchewan farmers. The government brought in a program of $170 million, announced by the Minister of Agriculture a few days ago. He just referred to another $65 million that the Government of Canada is working on with respect to farmers.
I would tell my hon. friend this. This government increased aid to agriculture, including western agriculture, over the eight year period by 650 per cent. It has provided more aid to agriculture than any government in the history of Canada and we are working with farmers to do more.

Mr. Speaker, 1.6 million Canadians are out of work. Given this and given our very limited financial resources, I would like to ask the minister of defence why this government is spending $4.3 billion on helicopters instead of programs that would get Canadians back to work right now. Where are this government's priorities?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of National Defence and Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, some years ago the party of which the hon. member is now a member of Parliament had a defence policy that called for the building and the deployment of frigates by the Canadian navy.
The purchase of the EH-101 helicopters is an essential part of that program because to deploy those frigates without helicopters is like building aircraft carriers without airplanes.
What I would like to know from the hon. member is whether the Liberal Party has a defence policy or if it has abandoned the policy that it initiated when it was government and which was carried on by this party when it became government to deploy the properly equipped frigates with the helicopters which are their essential eyes and ears.

February 1, 1993
Oral Questions
I would point out that as a result of the very good industrial benefits negotiated by this government in the course of developing this particular defence procurement, there is very significant employment for Canadians in fulfilling this important defence priority. It will have long term industrial benefits for Canada.

Mr. Speaker, we do have priorities such as the 1.6 million Canadians who do not have jobs today.
This is why I want to ask again: Why does this minister have funds to enter into partnerships with foreign governments when it does not have the funds to enter into programs to renew our municipalities and reconstruct our devastated manufacturing sector?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of National Defence and Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member and his party are veiy quick to stand up in this House and urge the Government of Canada to participate in international operations for peacekeeping and peacemaking. They appear to want to have our men and women in the Canadian Armed Forces fulfil that obligation without being properly equipped.
I would suggest that the 45,000 person-years of employment that result from this contract are not insignificant. The bottom line of this is the well-being and safety of Canadians in terms of the search and rescue capabilities of these helicopters and in terms of their ability to protect the people who serve in the Canadian Armed Forces.

Mr. Speaker, the last minister of defence to stand in this House and defend with such enthusiasm an absolutely essential defence priority was the minister of communications who in 1987 announced the $10 billion nuclear submarine program.
Of course that was followed quickly by the Prime Minister who announced the $1 billion Polar 8 ice-breaker, followed again by the program for a northern terrain vehicle, nearly $1 billion, announced in Alberta just before the last election. All three have vanished into thin air.
I say with great respect to the Minister of Finance, cut out the bluster and simply tell 1.6 million unemployed Canadians why they must stay grounded while this minister builds a Cadillac helicopter fleet.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of National Defence and Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Perhaps the hon. member could explain to this House why his party thinks it is appropriate to send Canadian men and women aloft in 30-year old aircraft.

Mr. Speaker, this party does not think it appropriate to send men and women in any field of endeavour without appropriate equipment, but we think it inappropriate to purchase a Cadillac system at a time when the Prime Minister says the deficit is so high he cannot put $1 into job creation.
I want to ask this Minister of National Defence and this government to recognize that the cold war in 1993 is being fought on the streets of Canada by Canada's unemployed and will it get its priorities straight once and for all in advance of an election?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of National Defence and Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, perhaps that hon. member will explain to the fishermen of Newfoundland who may have their lives saved by helicopters that are able to stay airborne for five hours instead of two hours, that are able to fly in weather conditions we now do not have the capability to fly in, and perhaps he will tell the families of the people who are saved by those helicopters when they perform their search and rescue functions that he regrets that we had a Cadillac helicopter to save their lives.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of National Defence and Veterans Affairs.
On the weekend a report was released in Britain that is critical of the Canadian forces who served in Hong Kong in World War II. They were men of the Royal Rifles of Canada and the Winnipeg Grenadiers and a contingent of Canadian Army nurses. I have been to Hong Kong and viewed the battleground with the survivors of that conflict. I have visited the cemeteries and read the headstones of the young men and women who gave their lives. None of the headstones read coward or drunkard or any of the derogatory comments that appear in the report.
February 1, 1993

Would the minister care to comment on this secret report attributed to the late Major General Maltby?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of National Defence and Minister of Veterans Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know that in responding to this question I speak not just for the government but for all members of this House.
I have seen the responses of a number of distinguished Canadian historians to the comments of Major General Maltby and I think all agree that there is no historical basis for his comments.
I do not think it is necessary to speculate on why he made those comments, but simply to remind all Canadians, as all members of this House are aware, that the battle of Hong Kong was a terrible one, that there were grievous losses and in fact the survivors of that battle are among the most important clients of the Department of Veterans Affairs and receive the most comprehensive health benefits and that there was in that terrible battle one Victoria Cross awarded and that Victoria Cross was awarded to Major John Osborn of the Winnipeg Grenadiers.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Attack, attack, attack. I wonder if this government does not have anything better to do than to attack the unemployed in this country.
I would like to know from the minister just how reducing the benefits from 60 per cent to 57 per cent will help the unemployed in this country. It does not leave them enough money to take a bus to go look for jobs that do not even exist.
When is this government going to stop attacking the unemployed, do something realistic and create some jobs for these people? They are getting sick and tired of this nonsense.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows what the reduction from 60 per cent to 57 per cent effectively does. It freezes the UI benefits. Those who are currently receiving UI at current levels will continue. That is grandfathered.
Oral Questions
The hon. member knows that because of the maximum insurable earnings adjusted upward there would in effect be an increase of 3 per cent to 4 per cent. At a time when many employees across the country are having their salaries frozen and indeed having their salaries reduced, it was certainly appropriate to take this initiative.
The alternative is to increase UI premiums, which is another form of tax upon the working men and women of this country, the small businesses and all the employers of this country. It is a time when everyone has to tighten up to meet the difficult deficit challenges that we face. I hoped the hon. member would understand it in that light.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport. It has to do with a recommendation by a group of consultants hired by the National Transportation Review Commission that would lead to further unemployment in this country in the tens of thousands. That has to do with the recommendation that 23,000 jobs be cut from Canada's rail industry.
I want to ask the Minister of Transport when this government will realize that the answer to what is wrong with the transportation system is not in getting rid of more and more jobs in that very industry, but in admitting that deregulation and free trade are killing the transportation industry in this country and setting about re-regulating the transportation industry.
If the minister is not willing to do that, will he agree, because he has that report now, to release it and to convene a meeting of all the stakeholders in our transportation industry, not just the companies, but unions and communities and everyone else concerned, so that we can finally do what is right by Canada's transportation industry.

Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member wants to quote some excerpts from that report he should also refer to the contents of that report which say that deregulation has been of great benefit to all stakeholders in the transportation industry in Canada, especially the clients and the shippers.

Oral Questions
The report he is referring to is one of the reports requested by the National Transportation Review Committee. It is part of the report. We will table our response to this report as soon as we have had a chance to go through this report that was tabled last Friday.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Supply and Services.
The federal and provincial governments in the mari-times are working really hard to eliminate interprovincial trade barriers but the Department of Supply and Services in Moncton has its own little interprovincial trade barrier. The Moncton office will go west 300 or 400 kilometres to buy from businesses, they will go north to P.E.I. to buy from businesses, but they will not go 50 kilometres east into Nova Scotia to buy from Nova Scotia businesses.
Will the minister open this trade barrier up to Nova Scotia businesses and do the right thing?

The government promised changes to the Young Offenders Act by the fall. The fall has come and gone and we still do not have these changes. Canadians are becoming alarmed.
Why is the government refusing to make these much needed changes to the Young Offenders Act?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend knows that we made some changes in May with Bill C-12 addressing some issues that Canadians were concerned with.
My hon. colleague, the Solicitor General, and myself are contemplating other amendments to this legislation and we will talk with Canadians in the weeks to come as well. We have a symposium, and I think my hon. friend will be there, in Toronto with all stakeholders-police officers, all groups and provinces-to get together to decide what is best to ensure that people will feel more secure in this country.

Mr. Speaker, Bill C-12 was passed over a year and a half ago. Even before it was passed his predecessor said that more changes were needed to the Young Offenders Act. We still do not have those changes.
Does this government need a symposium to tell it that the Young Offenders Act is flawed? Does the government need a three-day symposium to tell it what to do? Is this government so out of control on the question of law and order that it cannot make up its own mind, or is it just stalling?

I already said that my predecessor had already spoken about our intention to go ahead and we will do that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The government seems to have adopted the policy of doing the opposite of everything Quebec wants, be they business executives, workers, the Liberal Government of Quebec-its ally-or the Official Opposition of Quebec. This is especially true of the federal government's refusal to withdraw from the manpower field, a field that we know is essential for economic recovery.
I therefore ask the government and the Prime Minister why they stubbornly insist on maintaining the present imbroglio, which is paralyzing the efforts of all governments, and why they refuse to withdraw from a field where efficiency requires that there be only one authority, namely Quebec.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs):

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is well known that a national referendum was held, with a certain result. Therefore we cannot proceed with the constitutional changes as such, but it would be quite possible for us to have discussions with the provinces, Quebec as well as the others, on arrangements that could change the status quo here in Canada.
We want a country that works; we are not trying to have an Italian-style country and Parliament.

That kind of
answer is avoiding the issue! Mr. Speaker, I think that we can say that that is the classic answer of all successive governments that have refused to comply with Quebec's most legitimate demands.
The saddest part is to see that there are always members from Quebec, be they New Democrats, Liberals or Conservatives, to support these unfair measures against Quebec.
I ask the Prime Minister whether he realizes that he is burning his last bridges with Quebec.

We are talking about the manpower field.

subtopic: THE LATE RIGHT HONOURABLE JEANNE SAUVE
THE LATE RIGHT HONOURABLE JEANNE SAUVE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it was in this House that from the beginning of her political career Jeanne Sauve was to radiate her remarkable personal qualities and her profound love of this country.
She was a member of Parliament for 10 years, most of which were spent as a minister of the government of that time. Subsequently, from 1980 to 1983, she presided over the proceedings of this House. I am sure you, Mr. Speaker, will appreciate that this responsibility may at times be a very heavy burden for the Speaker of a democratic House such as this one.
Those among us who sat in the Commons at the same time as Madam Sauve will remember above all that she drew strength and serenity from an optimistic and generous vision of Canada's future.
Although she was an eager and able participant in the partisan give and take that is an entirely natural expression of one's political commitment, she never forgot that our first duty as a member is to serve our fellow citizens and our country.
As parliamentarians, while we mourn the passing of an esteemed and respected colleague, we also admire a career that was outstanding in every respect.
May her memory always be an inspiration to us and to those who some day will be our successors.

February 1, 1993
Tributes
As Governor General she represented our country with a natural dignity and generosity that was appreciated by all, from the average citizen to the leaders of this world. Since we first met more than 25 years ago, I have appreciated the warmth of her personality and the strength of her convictions.
Since I was first elected as Prime Minister of Canada and until the end of her mandate as Governor General in 1990, her advice, encouragement and of course her friendship were much appreciated. I will always consider it a rare privilege, in the course of my public career, to have served my country in the company of this great lady.
Jeanne Sauve was sincere in her conviction that Canada is more than the sum of its parts, that British Columbia, the west, Ontario, Quebec and the Atlantic provinces, with all their differences and similarities, together form the most splendid country on earth. She always showed as much confidence in our future as she did pride in our past.
Her most precious legacy to us and to future generations is her exemplary dignity, lucidity and unshakable confidence, especially when coping with the illness she was to experience during the last 10 years of her life.

Jeanne Sauve possessed many remarkable qualities. A person of deep religious faith she was also acutely aware of and sensitive to the realities that exist in a great pluralistic society. She was a committed foe of intolerance and racism in all of their forms. She was equally blessed with a sharp and inquisitive mind and an exuberant sense of humour. She expected others to meet the same high standards that she always demanded of herself. Yet she abounded in compassion for those who from time to time fell short through no fault of their own.
In her public life, as in private, I always thought that she was a supremely gracious person. She brought to every office and to every task a measure of quiet dignity and effortless appearance which enriched and impressed all with whom she dealt.
Above all, Jeanne Sauve was a passionately committed Canadian. She loved Canada with every fibre of her being and she came to represent Canada. She was a French speaking young woman from Prud'homme, Saskatchewan, who became one of the builders of modern Quebec and yet felt so at home in English speaking
Canada. She came to represent the very best values that all of Canada stands for, both here and around the world. She was keenly aware of the diversity of Canada and she applied that awareness in ways that always strengthened our citizenship.
With the support of her late husband, the hon. Maurice Sauve who also served in this House with distinction and whom many of us remember very fondly as well, she became the first woman elected to this House from the province of Quebec. Obviously talented, she was soon appointed to cabinet where she successfully discharged many portfolios. As Speaker of this House she implemented significant administrative reforms which have greatly improved the efficiency of the institution.
Her years as Governor General were characterized by an admirable combination of verve and dignity, proof if ever it was needed that style and substance are not mutually exclusive. Her Majesty was extremely well served by Jeanne Sauve's tenure at Rideau Hall.
After an exceptionally full life of service she continued to devote herself to noble causes, and in a very special way to the cause of the youth. She caused to be created the Jeanne Sauve Youth Foundation to stimulate in our young people and the youth of other countries the creativity and initiative that she herself displayed throughout her entire life.
With other members of Parliament which I see here today, I was at the first Jeanne Sauve Conference for Youth that took place in Montreal. The Secretary-General of the United Nations was the principal guest, and it then broke down into four days of seminars, discussions, and debate. It was an exhilarating and genuinely impressive experience.
At the end of the day the conference was all about tolerance and the fundamental values of citizenship, and about encouraging these young men and women from around the world to assume positions of leadership in their own countries when they returned to them.
Those who knew her well understood that nothing brought more joy to the lives of Jeanne and Maurice Sauve than their son, Jean-Franqois. He was truly the apple of her eye and no mother could have been prouder of a son.
February 1, 1993

I remember well that her smile was never brighter and her eyes never more expressive than when she talked about Jean-Frangois, her family and those she held dear.
To Jean-Frangois and his wife Diane I extend my very deep personal condolences.

Speaking on behalf of the Government of Canada, of all members of this Elouse and of all Canadians, I wish to express to Jean-Frangois and all members of his family our feelings of profound admiration for the historic endeavour of Jeanne Sauve and to extend our sincere condolences.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
subtopic: THE LATE RIGHT HONOURABLE JEANNE SAUVE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, like the Prime Minister, I rise in turn to pay tribute to this great lady who was our colleague in the House of Commons.
The members of my party benefited from her company and her advice for 12 years when she was a member of this House.
She was a quite remarkable woman. She was very learned and had travelled around the world, but she still remained unpretentious. Everywhere she went, she loved to meet young people and we felt that Jeanne Sauve represented the best of Canada. I think that she is the finest example we could give Canadian youth.
As the Prime Minister just said, she came from a small French speaking village in Saskatchewan and spent part of her youth in Ottawa. Later she was quite at home in Montreal's artistic and journalistic community. When she came to this House in 1972 she was already very well known, both in Canada and abroad.
She was always very diligent in the many cabinet positions she held. She was very interested not only in her own department but in what was happening throughout the government. She was always the first. In the tributes paid to her it was mentioned that she was first in school and she was also first here. She was the first French speaking woman from Quebec appointed to cabinet. She was the first woman Speaker of this House and, of course, to crown her career, she became Governor General of Canada. She filled that position with a style that had not previously been matched.
When she retired she wanted to go on. It was very much in the character of Jeanne Sauve because when
Tributes
she was a young person she was involved with young people. She tried to organize them. She tried to make sure they would find a comfortable place in society in Canada as La jeunesse etudiante catholique: comment se trouver une place dans la societe canadienne.
She decided to spend the last year of her life trying to get the young people of the world together because she fundamentally understood there was no difference among human beings. It did not matter what language they spoke, what religion they professed, what was the colour of their skin or what gender they belonged to; it made no difference to Jeanne Sauve. What she always sought was to make invaluable what is the best in every human being. Until the last weeks of her life she worked at trying to bring the young people of the world together.
As was said by the Prime Minister, Jeanne Sauve was probably the greatest lady we have known in public life in Canada in this century. I had the pleasure of serving with her and her husband. It is very rare to see a family so completely committed to public life. Both had the feeling that when you are in public life, you can make a difference if you work hard at it. We can say that this couple was a great asset to this House of Commons and to the country.
On behalf of the party that Jeanne Sauve served in, I would like to express to her son and his wife our deepest regrets. He can be proud he is the son of two great Canadians. Jeanne Sauve was, among all Canadians I have known, one of the greatest persons I have had the pleasure to spend time with and work with. God bless her soul.

subtopic: THE LATE RIGHT HONOURABLE JEANNE SAUVE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I also rise to grieve the passing of Jeanne Sauve, a Canadian whose work in public life was a model for all Canadians. Her accomplishments truly were remarkable, as the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition have noted.
Jeanne Sauve began at a very young age, at 20, as national president of the Jeunesse etudiante catholique. Later she became head of la Federation des mouvements de jeunesse du Quebec, an employee of UNESCO in Paris, a mother, a wife, a prominent Quebec journalist, a member of Parliament, a member of cabinet, Speaker of this House, Governor General, and most recently head of a scholarship fund which had as its goal bringing together world youth.

February 1, 1993
Tributes
While remarkable achievements in themselves, they were more significant because Jeanne Sauve was often a trail blazer and her efforts made it easier for others who followed.

She was the first woman from Quebec to be appointed minister. She was the first woman Minister of the Environment, the first woman Speaker of this House, the first woman Governor General.
Madam Sauve belonged to this very special breed of people who give dignity to their tasks without ever shying away from a challenge.

I have been personally inspired by Madam Sauve's steadfast conviction to change, her conviction in spite of obstacles that were often in her way. Of special importance was Madam Sauve's drive to create space and funds for on site day care for children of the House of Commons' employees. She was not a woman to shy away from controversy when it came to principle.

As Governor General she made a number of people jump with the stand she took on the Meech Lake accord, when she argued passionately that Quebec had always been a distinct society, and she said so because she was convinced it was her duty to promote national unity.

Madam Sauve once said that the role of the Governor General was to meet people, make them conscious of the presence of the Crown and the importance of the Constitution to their country, comfort them, manifest enthusiasm over what they were doing because it is an encouragement trying to foster national unity. It is fitting that in her last years she would again focus on the issue of youth in Canada and around the globe.
Madam Sauve will be fondly remembered by many. While there is great sadness in her passing, there is also great respect for what she has done for the people of Canada.
On behalf of my party, I would like to express our condolences to her son Jean-Francois, his wife and family and simply to say that thanks to his mother and father, Maurice Sauve, Canada is a better place. They will both be missed.

subtopic: THE LATE RIGHT HONOURABLE JEANNE SAUVE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I knew Madam Sauve and had the opportunity to see her at work both on the home front and abroad. Whatever she did, she did with distinction, intelligence and passion.
Her view of her role as Governor General was more Canadian and activist than that of most of her predecessors. She travelled more extensively abroad in her official capacity and never hesitated to carry out, to the fullest, the role of head of state for Canada.
She was also the first Governor General whose status of head of state was recognized in France during an official visit to that country. In addition, she did not hesitate to call upon the open-mindedness of her fellows citizens to urge them to ratify the Meech Lake accord. Not one of those who have had the honour to be in contact with her will forget the pleasantness of her conversation and the nobility of her views.
I wish to pay the last honours to this great lady on behalf of the members from the Bloc Quebecois and to reiterate all the respect and admiration I had for her. To her son and daughter-in-law, I offer my deepest sympathy.

I would like to remind all members that they have until six o'clock this evening to go to the Rotunda to sign the register in memory of the late Right honourable Jeanne Sauve.
There is another tribute this afternoon for a former colleague of many of us in this House, Charles Turner.
February 1, 1993

Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to pay tribute to a former member of this House and of the Senate, the Hon. Charles Thmer, who on January 10, 1993 at the age of 76 passed away in London, Ontario.
He served the constituents of London East and Canadians very well between 1968 and 1984 in this House. He was appointed to the Senate by the Right Hon. Pierre Trudeau in 1984 where he served until 1991 at his retirement.
He was known to most who served with him as Choo-Choo Charlie because of his locomotive engineering background. Most will recall that he was an officer of this House, being Whip of the government of the day. I suppose some will fondly remember the great bell escapade in March 1982 when for 15 days the bells rang. As a faithful servant of this House, Charlie brought his bed into the lobby and stayed there for a number of days protecting the government of the day.
In London East Charlie was known for his big heart. He was a big man with a very big heart. He was a man with a common touch who at no hour of the day hesitated to serve his constituents by delivering a passport or an unemployment insurance form. You name it and Charlie did it.
Charlie loved serving the people. He loved his job here and he loved the Senate. His contributions were many. While he was here he spoke frequently about transportation and safety, unemployment insurance, portable pensions and pensions for veterans, workers' rights, and an end to pollution in Lake Erie.
This is a trademark of the quality of this man. He said that it was the little guy that makes the world go around. The big guy is nobody if he does not have the little guy to do the work. That is what Charlie was all about.
To his wife, Marjorie and his daughters, Charmaine and Gloria, and his three grandsons, we on this side of the House pay our deep respect and convey our deep condolences to the family. He was a great man who will
Tributes
never be forgotten, not in London East and not in this House or in the Senate.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to say a few words on behalf of my party about Charlie Thmer.
I was first elected in 1968 and Charlie Turner was one of the class of 68. He was successfully re-elected in 1972, 1974, 1979 and 1980. When Mr. Trudeau ceased to be Prime Minister, Mr. Tbmer was appointed to the Senate. He was a Senator from 1984 until his retirement. For awhile our responsibilities in the House overlapped. He was the chief government Whip and I was the Whip of the New Democratic Party for part of that time.
Charlie was very well liked as a member of Parliament. For those who did not know him, he was one of those members who was liked on all sides of the House. He was one of the so-called ordinary people elected to this place who never lost the common touch with the ordinary person in his riding or elsewhere in the country.
If you wanted to know what was happening and wanted to get the pulse of ordinary Canadians, Charlie Thmer was one of the members of Parliament you could count on to have that knowledge at his fingertips. I can remember the Prime Minister of the day, Pierre Trudeau, saying that he often consulted Charlie Turner when he wanted to know what was going on among ordinary people across the country.
On behalf of my party, I want to express to his wife, his daughters and his grandchildren our deepest condolences and sympathy. We will miss Charlie Thmer. This House is a much better place because of Charlie Thmer and we will miss him.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister for Science and Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise on behalf of the people of the city of London, and particularly London West which I represent, and on behalf of our party to add my words of condolence to Marjorie, her two daughters and grandchildren on the passing of Charlie Thmer.
We have just paid tribute to Jeanne Sauve and we are now paying tribute to Charlie Thmer. It shows the glory of this institution. Madam Sauve was the Speaker and later the Governor General. Mr. Thmer had the common touch and everybody who served with him in this House remembers him with tremendous affection. Charlie Thmer, as my hon. friend just said, liked to articulate the needs of the ordinary person, the small guy.

Tributes
I remember very well having lunch with him the first week I was elected in 1984. He told me that one of the secrets to getting re-elected was to deliver the passport personally to the front door, because you have to find ways to make contact with the constituent. "Don't send it through the mail, Tom. Take it yourself". He was searching for ways to reach out to the average person. Nobody was more successful in the history of London's political life than Charlie Tbmer at doing that.
He was named Choo-Choo and he had the image of the average guy's politician. Wherever you were with Charlie Turner, people would approach him and treat him as if he was their uncle or older brother. He had an accessibility which all of us admired enormously.
Charlie's greatest concern was when organizations got big: big business, big unions, big institutions. He was afraid they would lose touch with what ordinary people were saying. He used to talk about that. He always tried to make a connection to the average person in order to make sure these big institutions, be it government, Parliament, a union, a company or an institution, did not get out of touch with whom they represented?
The people of London were proud to have him as one of their members of Parliament. They were proud they had somebody whom the Prime Minister of the day trusted so fully, as Prime Minister Trudeau did. They were proud to have somebody who was from their part of the world and who had gone through the economic growth of southern Ontario in a way that would make an ordinary person proud.
As a member of Parliament from London, I have always looked at Charlie Turner as a model of how to be a constituency MP and colleague. I know this House will join with me in saluting his memory.

Mr. Speaker, as one who knew Charlie Turner from the day he came into the House, I want to say today to Marjorie, his two girls and the rest of the family that they have every right to be very proud of Charlie Tbmer.
He was indeed a grassroots representative of his riding. He was a grassroots representative of the people in London, simply because he came from the average walk of life? He came into this House having spent many years as a railroad engineer.
When he was Whip of the Liberal Party Charlie faced some tough days and some tough issues. We would tease him because he ran the Whip's office just as he would a steam engine or locomotive on the railways. He had a heart. Deep down he was a very kind-hearted individual, but he was one who wanted to get the job done.
He had a very close liaison with the labour community, not only of the railroads but also other industrial bases across this country. He was respected by people right across Canada from coast to coast to coast.
Everybody in this House certainly knows there is not a much tougher job that a person can be given than to be Whip of a political party. The Whip has to deal with every single member. Charlie was able to do that on an individual basis. When he had a tough decision to make, he made it, but he made it with fairness.
I consider it to have been a great pleasure to have worked with Charlie Tbmer for several years. I consider it an act of respect that one of the other members in this House today said that he kept touch with the common individual because he came from the average walk of like.
He has given all of us a lesson. As we sit in this House today and in the days to come, if we use Charlie Tbmer's ideas and his empathy for people who are having difficult times, we will certainly be emulating the great example that Charlie Tbmer gave to this House and to the working people across this nation.
Today I want to say to Marjorie and to Charlie's and Marjorie's two daughters that we thank them for giving us Charlie Turner in this House for a long time. We respect the work he has done. We are with them today in telling them to keep their chins up. They have every right to be proud. We only hope that the people of
February 1, 1993

Canada will remember the Charlie Tbmers of this world. They too are outstanding representatives in this nation.

Mr. Speaker, I got to know Charlie Tbmer between 1979 and 1984 in the transport committee on the opposition side and of course on the government side.
As my predecessors have already mentioned, he was a grassroots politician. He brought the concerns of the average worker, whether it was from CN or CP, to the transport committee. I remember how hard Charlie fought for better pensions for the retirees. Some had retired from CN with very inadequate pensions. They wanted to make representations to the transport committee and Charlie Tbrner made sure they were represented there.
When we were crossing Canada with the western transportation and grain handling act, known as the Crow bill, Charlie Turner fought for not cutting branch lines. People do not know this about Charlie. He had the foresight to know that if branch lines were cut it would be the end of many family farms in Saskatchewan and Manitoba. Charlie saw that and he fought to preserve the branch lines. Charlie has added a lot.
Yes, Marjorie, his two daughters and grandchildren can be very proud of another great Canadian who has made his niche in the history of Canada.
I got to know him as our party Whip. Charlie practised what I call the three Fs in life. He was firm. He was fair. He was friendly. I pay tribute to Charlie Tbrner, a great parliamentarian, a great Canadian.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to extend my condolences to Charlie Timer's family. He and I were elected in 1968 along with almost 100 other new members.
He was an expert in the field of transportation having been an engineer on the railroad. He not only was an authority in caucus and in the House on railroad and transportation issues but he was also capable of regaling us with great stories about his years on the CNR.
He was a staunch supporter of Mr. Trudeau and ultimately was the chief government Whip during the difficult times of the bell ringing incident during the early 1980s.
His great supporter of course was Marjorie. She would often be on the Hill. He was dedicated to his riding. He drove home practically every weekend from Ottawa to
Tributes
London. He loved to attend all the public functions in his riding, to meet and greet and be well known by his constituents.
I simply want to join in the words of condolence that have been spoken in the House to Marjorie, their daughters, and their grandchildren. He really was a great constituency person, a great parliamentarian, and ultimately a great senator. He will be missed.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to add some very personal words on the death of Charlie Timer. I frankly did not know he had passed away during the break until I heard the words expressed here today. I am not going to repeat everything that has been said.
I first got to know Charlie when he came here in 1968 on the transportation committee. I was in the opposition and he was a government man. Charlie was fair, civil and had that manner of respect for fellow colleagues regardless of what side of the fence they stood on, something that is getting to be a rare commodity around here. I agree with all those who have said he was the model of a constituency member. I do not know what he did in the Senate, but I know that in this House of Commons he added a note of civility and common sense that is much needed around here.
I got to know his wife Marjorie because, as the member for Algoma has just said, she was always around. I certainly want to extend to her and the family my sympathy for their loss.
In closing, everything has been said in a sense. I can see the common thoughts he gave as the member for London, as parliamentary secretary to the minister of science and technology. One of the things I am going to miss now that I have heard these eulogies today is his great sense of humour. Boy, you need a sense of humour around here too.
There was that belly laugh and a smile which really did captivate and came out at times when there was tension and strain. I think that helped all of us from time to time.
I am glad I was in the House to hear the statement earlier today and to acknowledge the many years I shared with Charlie, regardless of the fact we were on opposite sides of the fence. It did not make any difference in terms of respect for each other. We were each trying to do our thing in making this a better place, and he certainly tried to make this House and the country a better place.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today on a question of privilege which arose on December 11, 1992, the last day the House sat before the Christmas break. During Question Period at that time I had asked the government if it would produce the full financial statements for Hockey Canada, a public agency. The member for Vancouver Centre responded on behalf of the government. I quote from Hansard of that day at page 15105:
I will take that question on behalf of my colleague, the Solicitor General, who has indicated that this matter is currently being investigated by the RCMP The Government of Canada will offer no further information until the RCMP has concluded its investigation.
This answer was interesting in itself, Mr. Speaker, since the Solicitor General has never indicated to this House or publicly, to my knowledge, that such an investigation was ongoing by the RCMP. More important, however, six days later the chairman of the board of Hockey Canada, Mr. Ian Macdonald, released a statement saying:
The suggestion that the RCMP are investigating the financial records of Hockey Canada is simply not true. No one in Hockey Canada has had any conversations with the RCMP concerning such an investigation, nor have any of our records been examined by them. It is difficult to determine from where such reports emanated.
The question of privilege is simple. Either the member for Vancouver Centre misled the House or an Order in Council appointee to a government agency is refuting the words of a minister of the Crown and casting aspersions on the proceedings of this House.
I would like to quote from the 19th edition of Erskine May, chapter X, page 144 under the heading "Constructive Contempts", subheading "Speeches or Writings Reflecting On Either House":
In 1701 the House of Commons resolved that to print or publish any books or libels reflecting on the proceedings of the House is a high violation of the rights and privileges of the House.
Also noted in this passage of Erskine May is:
Reflections upon members, the particular individuals not being named or otherwise indicated, are equivalent to reflections on the House.
Although Mr. Macdonald did not publish a book, he did in fact cast aspersions on the proceedings of this House. In the 1990s the press release of a statement is equivalent to a published document. It is circulated instantly and widely to millions of Canadians across this country.
Mr. Macdonald's press release of December 17, of which I have a copy and will provide to the Chair at the completion of my remarks, was based on the proceedings in the House during Question Period. There is no doubt of the source in the minds of the public who watched Question Period on December 11, 1992 and the media who reported the exchange on national television and in daily newspapers across this country. Mr. Macdonald was clearly upset by the proceedings in the House when he admitted to The Toronto Star on December 18, 1992: "I cannot describe how frustrating it is to pick up the paper and be connected with something like that".
This is not the case of the opposition and the government disagreeing. We are not talking about a dispute over facts that the Official Opposition and the government engage in during our daily accountability sessions. We are talking about a government agency which spends taxpayers' money in its deliberate attempt to bring into disrepute the proceedings of this House.
We in this House, as I think you have evidenced on many occasions, take seriously the honour of taking a member at his or her word. A senior public servant has publicly refuted what a minister of the Crown placed on the record of this House. The question was a simple informative question and the answer was simple: There is an RCMP investigation.
What has transpired since the House adjourned has been confusing and contradictory. The taxpayers of Canada have a right to know how their taxes are being used. That is essentially why we are here. One of the
February 1, 1993

main roles of the Official Opposition is to hold the government accountable. I do not believe the opposition or the government are able to do their jobs and to do them well when the head of a public agency publicly disputes the proceedings of this House.
In Erskine May the definition of contempt is as follows, and I quote from page 143 of the 20th edition:
It may be stated generally that any act or omission which obstructs or impedes either House of Parliament in the performance of its functions, or which obstructs or impedes any Member or officer of such House in the discharge of his duty, or which has a tendency, directly or indirectly, to produce such results may be treated as a contempt even though there is no precedent of the offence.
We asked a question in this House. We are told that we cannot have an answer because of an RCMP investigation pertaining to the question we have raised. Then the chairman of the board attempts to refute the minister's answer claiming that no such investigation exists and this happened six days later.
The truth is missing somewhere behind the words of two responsible parties. We in this House are being impeded in performing our constitutional role of holding the government to account for the disposing of taxpayers' money. Our job in Parliament is to subject all Crown agencies to public scrutiny to show the wise use of tax dollars. We must be objective and, I suggest, constructive.
Public agencies that comment on the proceedings in this House are not conducive to us fulfilling our responsibilities. Indeed we believe them to be breaches of our privileges. Mr. Macdonald's actions are more than a disagreement with something said in the House. He is a public official who is attempting to prevent the House, I suggest, from getting the facts. It may well be that the responsible ministers will agree with me on this point.
In conclusion, Mr. Speaker, if you find a prima facie case, I am prepared to move the appropriate motion. On the other hand, if somehow the minister has inadvertently misled the House with regard to the RCMP investigation, we will want to hear why such a thing was allowed to stay on the books and to stay in the minds of the public for such an indefinite period of time while her colleague, the Solicitor General, sat idly by and responding with nothing in the interim.
