speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to respond to my hon. colleague's allegations. There's a suggestion that the time of the House and of members of Parliament and of the committee on privileges and elections should be used to pursue this matter.
First, it would be helpful to review the actual question to see how loose and rambling the actual question was. I am sure, Mr. Speaker, that when you have the opportunity you will agree with me.
My hon. friend started out by talking about Florida, then discussed the future of the league. He went on to suggest that serious questions had been raised recently about the financial dealings of the non-profit federal agency Hockey Canada and certain individuals. Then there was the direct question after the rambling that asked the minister responsible whether the government will provide to this House a full financial disclosure other than the annual one-line item expenses and income report for Hockey Canada since Hockey Canada has been incorporated.
The hon. minister replied. Bear in mind that it is a fact of life that we are often out of the House on business and she was responding on my behalf. I know that in no way would the hon. minister have ever misled the House. On this very simple case she had no cause to mislead the House.
Her answer is: "I will take that question". I am sure, Mr. Speaker, that when you review the text you will see that the question is: "Will the government provide to the House?" She undertook to take that question "on behalf of my colleague, the Solicitor General, who has indicated that this matter is currently being investigated by the RCMP. The Government of Canada will offer no further information until the RCMP has concluded its investigation." That is what took place in the House.
My hon. friend has not told the House something. I do not suggest for a minute that this was in an effort to mislead the House, but my hon. friend did not go on. I would not suggest for a minute that my hon. friend would deliberately mislead the House. However, my hon. friend neglected to point out to the House that there were comments made outside the House. Those of course are not something that would go to a matter of privilege based on a question answered in the House.

Privilege
It is quite fair to say that I am not briefed on behalf or acting on behalf of Hockey Canada, but I do have in my hands the same news release that my hon. friend referred to. In there Dr. Macdonald was quoted as saying: "The suggestion that the RCMP are investigating the financial records of Hockey Canada is simply not true. No one in Hockey Canada has had any conversation with the RCMP concerning such an investigation nor have any of our records been examined by them. It is difficult to determine from where such reports emanated".
There is no mention of the House of Commons in here. If one is going to be hauled before the bar of the House for defaming the House of Commons, one has to defame the House of Commons and the members in it.
I know my hon. friend is used to being referred to in the media in many places. Over the holidays, for example, he was in several newspaper accounts, that I believe I remember reading, with regard to certain difficulties he had in his party. I know he is used to being referred to in the media, but in this report there is no reference to the House of Commons. For one to defame the House of Commons one has to at least mention it.
I am sorry. I respect the desire for truth from members of Parliament. I have been on both sides of Question Period. I am sure that my hon. friend could pursue this matter under estimates. He made reference to the real question he is referring to, which is whether the government will provide to this House the full financial disclosure. That is the question my hon. friend asked.
The House knows there is a place to do this when the estimates of the government are considered. I think with all due respect to the time of the House and the items before the House that that is a matter to be dealt with at committee and I am sure we would be more than ready to entertain any questions on that line. I do not believe it is sufficient, but I am in your hands.

The Government of Canada will offer no further information until the RCMP has concluded its investigations".
What are we supposed to do in the opposition? If there is an RCMP investigation, that means we cannot get the information according to the Minister of Justice and not someone who is unfamiliar with the law.
My final point is that perhaps the Solicitor General would set the record straight. Is there an RCMP investigation of Hockey Canada or is there not?

Mr. Speaker, it is an honour and a privilege to present a petition on behalf of the Coalition of People Against River Diversion which recently held a two-day conference in Barriere, British Columbia. It was hosted by the North Thompson Indian Band and attended by a large number of participants including delegations from a variety of First Nations.
They point out that a firm by the name of Multinational Resources plans to divert the North Thompson River in order to sell the diverted water in the San Diego, California area.
They point out that this is simply part of the thinking flowing out of the NAWAPA plan. They know that at present the federal government has no legislation prohibiting the diversion of Canadian waters to the United States and therefore they are simply asking the government to state categorically that it will not permit our fresh waters to be dammed and diverted into the United States. They want the government to state that Canadian rivers and lakes are not for sale.

Mr. Speaker, I have a petition signed by 800 of my constituents in memory of Dawn Shaw, a little girl who was raped and murdered in the Comox Valley.
The petitioners have indicated their concern that children are increasingly becoming victims of sexual assault and they have proposed a number of measures to make our community safer for children. One measure is DNA testing of persons suspected of sexual assault.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to present a petition from a number of constituents in my riding who are concerned about co-op housing in this country.
The petitioners say that many Canadians have experienced serious housing problems and that the government terminated the federal co-operative housing program on February 25, 1992. They state that this action eliminated 2,000 new co-op units for 1992 alone, along
with 4,000 construction and manufacturing jobs for the same period.
They state that the indexed linked mortgage introduced in Canada by the co-op housing sector has substantially reduced the cost to the government of producing non-profit co-op housing. They state that there are approximately 164,000 renter households who want to move into co-op housing due to the success of the program in creating affordable and stable mixed income communities.
The petitioners therefore call upon Parliament to urge the government to immediately reinstate the federal co-operative housing program and to commit the $6.1 million to the program which had been planned for 1992 to permit approximately 2,000 co-operative housing units to be sponsored this year.

Mr. Speaker, my petition concerns the government cut in social housing by 34 per cent.
As a result of that cut many of the housing programs have been cancelled. There is a need for a strong federal presence in housing programs in order to ensure equal access to adequate and affordable housing, to which all Canadians have a right.
I join with my constituents who are calling on Parliament to urge the government to restore its planned commitment to social housing by reinstating many of the programs that it has cancelled.

Mr. Speaker, petitioners from across Canada are asking that the government remove the goods and services tax on books and other reading materials.
They point out that there has been a zero rate of tax since Confederation. They also emphasize that education is the cornerstone of increased productivity and increased competitiveness. They conclude by saying that the government ought to review its policies with regard to this tax.

Yes.
(a)	Initial work began on Canadian Cost Guard (CCG) levels of service in the late 1970s in response to concerns of the Auditor General, Treasury Board and Transport Canada internal audit. Several program evaluations and economic impact studies were initiated by CCG and carried out by groups such as the Bureau of Management Consulting, Sypher-Mueller Int. and Hickling Management Consultants. The Canadian Coast Guard issued an initial ice-breaking operations levels of service (LOS) document in October 1990, with instructions that the document was to be used for ice-breaking activity management and that it would be refined for continuing application thereafter. The LOS document provides clear definitions of icebreaking services that clients can expect. In simple terms it describes the what, where, when, how much and how fast, as well as limitations on and priorities for the available services. The LOS document is supported by data obtained from the ice-breaking Operations Data Information System (IODIS) and was refined on the basis of experience gained during the 1990-91 ice-breaking seasons in the Arctic and eastern Canada. During the fall of 1992 consultations were undertaken to make clients aware of the levels of ice-breaking services provided by the CCG and to solicit their comments on the program. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to resume my comments on Bill C-93 and more specifically its impact on the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council.
We hear a great deal of rhetoric from the government concerning the management of change. I do not think anybody in the Chamber would dispute that the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council is an important part of that approach to the future.
We know that the world of the future-Canada's future economically-will depend particularly on developing the service and information sectors of our economy. That depends on the expansion of knowledge in all fields. It depends on us having a commitment to the expansion of knowledge in science and research and in all fields.
It includes having a commitment to the development of expertise in a variety of fields as well as retaining the expertise that we have-our brain power-and developing international links to ensure that that can happen. Canadians must be able to learn in Canada and do research in Canada, but be well plugged in to the international scientific community and continue to practice in Canada as well.
We have been through a period in this country-I go back to the sixties for my first experience of it-when we did not have expertise in a variety of domains and continually had to import expertise and knowledge from other countries.
Now, 30 years later, we are looking at a situation where many of the people who came to this country at this time to contribute their knowledge and talents to Canada are saying to their children, who are now interested in various fields of science as well: "If you want a future as a scientist, do not stay in Canada. Go somewhere else".
Government Orders
We have seen what has happened to the National Research Council. We have seen the abandonment of the Science Council. I want to put this in a context because the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council plays as important a role in the development of our future as the development of the physical sciences.
The move proposed by the government to put the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council under the Council for the Arts in Canada shows a very limited view of the important role of this council. That is not in any way to denigrate the role of the Council for the Arts in Canada because it plays an important role, but it is a different role.
The science and humanities are linked in a very important way to the physical sciences. The important direction or trend in the development of human knowledge is the integration of different fields of science.
As I began to say before Question Period, the kinds of issues that we need to face increasingly mean that technical advancement does not come without repercussions throughout society. The management of technological change is more than a question of physical sciences. It is also a question of changes to the individual in society, changes fundamentally to our economy and changes to our society in a collective sense.
The importance we are giving now to the environment is a good example. Managing the problems of global destruction are more than a question of science in the traditional sense or the physical sense. It is very clear that if we are going to avoid the terrible damage that we have seen in our atmosphere, water and soils, we need to address the social dynamics as well as the physical dynamics.
In the field of biomedical science, it is not a question simply of technical advances, it is a question of how those technical advances are used. It is a question of what changes those bring to society as a whole. We only have to look at the question of reproductive technology to know that it is more than issue of developing the technology. It is also important to look at the social and personal implications of those developments.
When we talk about the development in the physical sciences of the ability to manipulate the very matter by which life is formed we know that it is not enough to deal with that knowledge as a physical science. The social implications of that science are equally important.
When we talk about a changing world in which lifelong training and education are going to be necessary, we know that more attention to society and humanity and how we adapt to change is vital if Canada is going to

Government Orders
profit from opportunities of the future without leaving our people behind. Adjustment brings with it more than dollar and business implications. It brings with it adjustment and turmoil.
We know we have a young generation that is facing more difficulty than previous generations in finding a place in that new economy. We know that we have a rising level of violence and racism. We know that whether we are going to be able to have the brains and talent we need to have in this country in the future depends on dealing with the issues of poverty. We know that we have an increasingly aging population that is going to require a different approach in many social policy areas.
We know that the future requires bringing many different fields of knowledge together and an increasing emphasis on the social and human implications of change. That is one of the important roles of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council. It is to ensure that we are understanding change, not just from the narrow physical science point of view, but from the broader implications for society as a whole. We are dealing with the disruption and the change to society that comes from progress in science.
We know it is important to set new economic directions. When change is occurring so rapidly, it is no longer enough to react to change. We know it is important to develop links both ways between the social sciences and the arts, as well as between the social sciences and the physical sciences.
Submerging one council in the other deprives both of the recognition of the important role they play in Canadian society. That certainly deprives the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of its ability to reach out to all fields of knowledge and to play the important role it should be playing as we plan our future.
Dealing with these issues requires leadership. It requires an understanding that the role of government is to provide that leadership. Instead we have seen the dismantling of the tools-in other bills that have come before us-by which that leadership has been provided. I have referred to the science council. I have referred to
the economic council and the council for oceans development. We have lost a number of institutions that I believe are important for Canada to seize the opportunities the future offers.
Understanding government and knowing what government is doing is an important part of that. Regrettably, one of the members who spoke earlier displayed, I think, an abysmal lack of knowledge about how government works.
The member for South Shore said something like what is the point of "the entire Government of Canada being in Ottawa?" If members of the government do not know that over 70 per cent of government offices and employees are not in the national capital region, then I am not quite sure how they expect to govern the country. If these members do not know that over 70 per cent of the people who work for the Government of Canada are in centres throughout the country, then they clearly might have a little difficulty deciding how to govern better.
If the member does not know, for instance, that there are 18,000 employees in the Public Service in Halifax,
12.000	in Vancouver, 20,000 in the Montreal region and
9.000	in Edmonton, he obviously is clearly uninformed about how government is operating now. I would have trouble having confidence in his ability to improve it.
The second point I want to make is that in exercising leadership the government has talked a great deal about partnership and consultation. It is all rhetoric. We have not had, in this major reorganization, the means to develop the intellect of our country, which is certainly our most important capital for the new era.
There has been no consultation whatsoever with the scientific community on these changes. What does that say about the commitment to partnership and to consultation? It undermines totally everything the government has said it planned to do in its prosperity agenda that spoke a great deal about partnership and consultation. It spoke a great deal about the need for science, research and technology development, yet we see a major change in that field without any partnership and without any consultation.
February 1, 1993

We may or may not be seeing a cost savings in this. The government has admitted as much. I think it is rather arrogant for a government in the last few months-possibly even the last few weeks of a mandate-to reorganize the structures of government and the structures by which Canadians are served.
I want to take just a few minutes to speak about the Cape Breton Development Corporation, which is another of the bodies dealt with in this bill. As I see it, one of the key elements in our future is to develop the abilities of communities to meet their own future needs and to develop their own future certainly with the partnership and the support of their federal and provincial governments.
If we believe that communities know their own strengths, people and opportunities best, then to fold an important agency like the Cape Breton Development Corporation into a larger regional agency seems to me to be going in the wrong direction.
I wanted to particularly refer to a comment made by the Solicitor General in response to one of my colleagues speaking on this very issue. It was the member for Cape Breton Highlands-Canso who was talking about the rising unemployment and the serious economic situation in Cape Breton. I am sure that situation is even worse now with the problems in the steel industry. In response to that the Solicitor General said: "That is because they vote Liberal".
The idea that a region should be punished because of how it votes is something that goes back to the day after the 1988 election when a well-known member of this House chose to say that Ottawa was going to be punished for voting Liberal. This is a democracy. People have the right to vote how they want to vote and still be entitled to the support of their government. I found that comment so offensive that I did have to refer back to it.
We see a disregard for people in this bill. We have no idea. Some people are coming from the Public Service, some people are coming from one council and some people are staying with the new council to be formed. We have again the government operating a kind of shell game when it says it is getting rid of employees in the Public Service. It is not really. It is just moving them out of the Public Service and into another agency which will continue to be funded by public dollars. This kind of
Government Orders
diversion and pretence really does not solve the problems of the country.
I also want to challenge the idea that bigger is necessarily better. Bigger agencies often just mean more levels of administration, reporting and accounting and not more productivity.
We have before us a poorly thought out bill. It was done with no consultation with those who are most directly affected and with the arrogance of a government that thinks it knows best for everybody and does not have to listen to anybody else.
We are abandoning a number of agencies that perform an increasingly important function as we face a changing future.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make a few comments with regard to the remarks just made. It is important that we be practical about what is going to happen under the various headings that the hon. member covered.
First, in terms of the amalgamation of the Canada Council with the SSHRC it is important to remember that the new council that will be formed will remain at arm's length from the government. The council will have full latitude to plan and establish its priorities to fulfil its mandate. The merger will also not affect the amount of support delivered to the two client groups. There was some intimation that might happen. That will not happen.
Funding for each group remains clearly distinct and the peer-review system for each will be maintained. The mechanism to do all this is still under discussion, but it is important that I put those comments on the record.
There will be some savings. Clearly the council itself will be smaller and there will be some other savings which I hope the hon. member supports. Her leader speaks about decreasing the deficit but I still have not found out how they will do it. This is one action that helps in a small way.
More important, she gave the impression that the granting councils are somehow under special attack. The truth is that this government has probably spent more money on native issues and science and technology than almost any other category of the federal government jurisdiction. Even the 10 per cent cuts on grants and

February 1, 1993

contributions announced in the last statement will not affect the granting councils.
The granting councils are not being affected by that 10 per cent cut. They went from four to zero but they will not be cut the whole 10 per cent, as is the rest of the government. This was our way of saying that this is a very special category.
It is also important because people lose track of this historically. Since we became the government in 1984 the research budget for the granting councils has increased 60 per cent. That is a huge increase given the tremendous fiscal pressures on the government.
It is important too, and this was not mentioned, that we remember that the Canada Scholarship Program has awarded over 12,500 scholarships valued at over $30 million to encourage students to study science at university. More than half of these have gone to women. We are providing more funds to the Industrial Research Assistance Program. We are permanently extending the networks of centres of excellence program which everybody salutes as a very good way to focus research.
There is also the Canadian Space Agency, drug research and the green plan. It is important to know what we have done to stimulate R and D spending through tax incentives. We are approving R and D tax incentives which will provide further R and D support of $230 million over the next five years. We are making it easier for Canadians to use federal science programs. Finally we have set aside $400 million to correct areas in which the tax system may slow the adoption of new technologies.
Science and technology are very important to this government. It is important that these points be made during this debate.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS) ACT 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, thank you for this opportunity to speak on Bill C-93, which is the Budget Implementation (Government Organizations) Act, 1992. It gives force to a number of mergers and in some instances the elimination of various bodies, as announced in the February budget of last year.
Many of the windings up and mergers are unexceptionable. They include the winding up of the Agricultural Products Board, and the merging of Enterprise Cape
Government Orders
Breton with ACOA. That is probably a reasonable thing to do, although we should be cognizant of the comments made earlier by another hon. member arguing that at least Enterprise Cape Breton had the merit of being local in its focus. There should be some effort even under ACOA and the other regional development agencies to ensure that there is local input and some degree of control over economic strategy in their regions.
It also merges the Canadian Commercial Corporation with the Department of Supply and Services. Emergency Preparedness Canada merges with the Department of National Defence. The Copyright Board, the Trademarks Opposition Board and the Patent Appeal Board are merged. The Procurement Review Board is merged with the Canadian International Trade Tribunal. The Petroleum Monitoring Agency's functions are taken over by the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources. The Veterans Land Administration's functions go to the Department of Veterans Affairs.
There are two changes which should raise some questions. The first is the merger of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police External Review Committee with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Public Complaints Commission. The first of these two bodies deals with grievances and appeals by officers and the second deals with complaints by citizens about bad behaviour or other difficulties with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
It is obvious that there is a significant conflict of functions involved in merging these two bodies, which I do not see justified in the arguments of the government for bringing about this change. This issue was cited by my colleague from North Island-Powell River. He highlighted the importance of the Public Complaints Commission in dealing with situations which although not common are all too common for the victims of those occasional instances of inappropriate actions on the part of the members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
Nevertheless, most of these changes are either provided with some justification in terms of functions or in terms of cost. One might find that almost all of these changes, with the exceptions I have noted, could be justified to reasonable people. However, that does not apply to Part III, which was described in the budget as a merger of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council with the Canada Council.

Government Orders
Nobody asked for it. There is no justification provided for it. No explanations have been presented to justify it. We heard the minister of science and technology dance all over a justification for it. He suggested that there might be some savings but provided no specifics of what the savings might be.
In fact just about everyone who has any interest in the issue at all very quickly indicated their opposition to this change. They expressed their shock that the government would initiate such a change without any consultation whatever and remain mystified to this day as to why the government would embark on this peculiar little exercise of merging a body that has to do with the support of research in academic institutions in the fields of social sciences and humanities with the Canada Council, which has to do with the support of creative and performing arts in this country.
It took a long time but culminating in 1978, after considerable evolution of the research enterprise in the social sciences and humanities in the universities, we arrived at the conclusion that the activities then included under the Canada Council should be separated to form the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council. This took place at a time when the National Science and Engineering Research Council and the Medical Research Council were separated from the NRC. Everybody with an ounce of sense thought it was a reasonable change. It was a change that resulted in a development that has been successful ever since.
These folks in their reasoning, as usual shallow as a mud puddle, jumped up with an idea that they were going to save some change. It comes down very simply to a manifestation of the substantially anti-intellectual bent of this government in a time when knowledge has become more important than it ever has been in history. It must be opposed to knowledge because ignorance seems to motivate almost everything it has done in recent weeks and months.
We have opposition from the Canadian Association of University Teachers, the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada, the Association of Canadian College and University Teachers of English, the National Consortium, the Canadian Federation for the Humanities and the Conference on the Arts. Everybody is opposed to this legislation.
Given that the government cannot in this instance, as in any other instance, be stopped in its momentum for stupidity, these various bodies have said we should try and make this legislation work somehow. One of things they noticed was that right off the bat, after reassuring the academic and arts community that the two separate identities of function would not be lost, that in fact the two would be merged, what we have in the title of the bill and the fact of the bill is in effect a subsuming of social sciences and humanities research under the Canada Council. Even the name of the new council suggests that. As you will note, the new name of this body would be the Canada council on the arts and so on, which means that just about anybody referring to it will be talking about the Canada Council as other activities will be lost in a name which will obscure this separate function.
The associations have suggested at the very least that this government rewrite the bill, not so that SSHRC is merged with the Canada Council, but the two bodies be merged together in a new unit that would not have reference to the Canada Council as the adopting agency. Rather it would give equal status to both in the name of a new agency which would not be shortened to obscure its functions.
The associations also raised the issue of the structure of the governing council.
The minister of science and technology said that the functions will continue and will be at arm's length, and all of that. First of all we have to look at who is going to go on the council of this new organization. Substantially all they have to do is have some familiarity or understanding of the activities in which the council is going to be engaged in order to be on the governing council.
There is no requirement that there be any specific number who understand research in the humanities and the social sciences, nor that they have specific experience or any reputation in the arts, or have any knowledge of the international activities of external affairs in any specific way. We suggest it should be necessary if it is going to be protected from government interference, because now we have a body that is just set up for government patronage. That is the way it is going to be.
February 1, 1993

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have an opportunity to speak on Bill C-93, legislation that was tabled in the House on February 25, 1992.
Quite frankly, the first day back after being away from the House of Commons for almost two months I find debating a bill which has to do with machinery of government so depressing. For me it does not have a heck of a lot to do with the real deep pain that is out there in the economy today.
As I was reviewing the bill I noticed in Part IV, which has to do with the Canadian Commercial Corporation, that we are moving it from the minister of industry and trade over to the Department of Supply and Services.
For those Canadians who are not aware of the Canadian Commercial Corporation, I would like to give a little bit of a backgrounder. This is a Crown corporation that assists Canadian companies in their efforts and in their ability to do medium and large international contracts. Most of them are defence related, but not exclusively. It helps small Canadian companies which do not have the ability to do some of these contracts on their own. The Canadian Commercial Corporation will come in and provide the stability and sometimes financial support, sometimes even management advice.
I am particularly interested in this agency of the government. I find it does not really matter where a piece of government machinery is located. What I mean by located is whether it is under the minister of industry or the Minister of Supply and Services, or if it is linked to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, wherever it is. It does not really matter what its location, what really matters is the attitude of the public servants to their job functions, their attitude in terms of service to the public.
We on this side of the House are not really adverse to reviewing government operations to try and streamline them from time to time. It is a normal activity. However I do not understand moving them for the sake of moving them.
In the case of the Canadian Commercial Corporation, I am really concerned that by moving it from one minister to another we are creating a situation which I
Government Orders
am not convinced is going to improve the efficiency. In fact I had a personal case where I found just the exact opposite.
I have in my riding a group of doctors who invested in a Canadian corporation based in Woodstock, Ontario. The name of the corporation is Amertek. This corporation won a military contract with the United States to produce military fire trucks. The contract was for close to 300 of them. Many of these fire trucks actually served in the Persian Gulf. They outbid the American firm Oshkosh which is an internationally recognized firm. Amertek is 100 per cent Canadian owned and 90 per cent of its product is exports, the kind of company that this government is always bragging about.
In the course of doing the contract the U.S. military came in and made close to 3,000 design changes. They went from a Chevrolet to a Cadillac in terms of military fire trucks. In fact these fire trucks are so good that there is one of them stationed at Camp David and another stationed at the White House in Washington.
This is what happened. These small entrepreneurs, because they had faith in the Canadian Commercial Corporation, did all of these extras and they have been waiting for two and a half years for the Canadian Commercial Corporation to process their extras.
Four years ago this company had close to $7 million in retained earnings. All of those retained earnings have been depleted. The investors put another $2.5 million to $3 million into the company. Now this company is having a very difficult time making it from payroll to payroll. Meanwhile there is close to $15 million worth of extras that are owed to them by the U.S. military.
My point is this. Here is an example where the will of the Public Service and the political will have really looked the other way when it comes to serving this small or medium sized enterprise. This is what bothers me about a debate like today's. It does not really matter where the Canadian Commercial Corporation is in terms of machinery of government. What we should be weaving into this debate and what we should be talking about is public service, the attitude of the public servants toward this small or medium sized company.

Government Orders
I am concerned about the fact that bureaucrats sometimes make these machinery of government changes and we as politicians are sold on them as being essential for efficiency, when in fact quite often they have nothing to do with efficiency.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling that I only have a couple of minutes left. I think the biggest danger when we make these changes is that we get involved in a system which I call the MAD treatment, maximum administrative delay.
Entrepreneurs who want to deal with government, who want support of government and then get involved in a contract cannot figure out why it takes months and months in order to get the proper response.
I appeal to the government, to all members over there and the minister responsible for the Canadian Commercial Corporation. If they really do believe that this bill is going to make the Canadian Commercial Corporation a streamlined, more productive unit, one that is supposed to serve the public, then I challenge them to pick up the file on Amertek on certification which has been sitting for almost two years.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was actually anticipating that one of my colleagues to my right might get up at this point in the proceedings. I hope you will forgive me if I am not as quick on my feet as you might have hoped.
I am pleased to participate in this debate and I want to deal with a very specific area in the act. As we have already heard the act deals with many different boards and tribunals in government.
The one I wish to address is Emergency Preparedness Canada which was established I believe in 1987 to deal with emergency preparedness.
On the surface the act is a very simple provision in respect of Emergency Preparedness Canada. It simply winds it up and turns over its functions directly to the Department of National Defence. At this point Emergency Preparedness Canada comes under the general responsibility of the Minister of National Defence. Therefore, the ultimate responsibility has not changed and does not change as a result of this act.
The act does end an experiment, if we can call it that, a decision made by this Parliament after very significant
thought in the early 1980s. There was considerable review of emergency preparedness in this country and the legislation pertaining to it. As a result of that consideration Parliament passed the Emergency Preparedness Act and established Emergency Preparedness Canada.
That decision is effectively being wiped out by this legislation. As far as I can tell it has done so without any public discussion or debate, without any reasons being advanced by the government for this change other than a cosmetic one to help the government politically respond to what it sees as a challenge from the Reform Party. I think the government owes it to the people of Canada and to this Parliament to explain its decision in this area far more carefully than it has.
I say that as the member for Victoria from Vancouver Island, where we have a very special concern and interest in emergency preparedness and particularly the risks and dangers to our area from earthquakes.
I wish to use this opportunity to refer the House and the people of Canada to the most recent report of the Auditor General. The report suggests that this government and therefore the Minister of National Defence who is responsible have been nothing short of grossly negligent in their responsibilities for emergency preparedness.
It is only by good luck that we have not yet had a major earthquake disaster on the west coast of Canada. The situation is that this government has left the people of that area bereft of emergency services that could effectively deal with such a catastrophe.
Emergency preparedness is the responsibility of all three levels of government and the municipal governments in our area have struggled to develop a response within their areas of jurisdiction. The Government of British Columbia is seeking to deal with it as well. However, as the Auditor General reveals the federal government has just delayed and delayed and delayed in getting to the heart of emergency preparedness to deal with the potential catastrophe of an earthquake on the west coast. We have seen five years pass as the Auditor General states it in which the government at a snail's pace has moved toward a national earthquake support plan.
February 1, 1993

On page 567 of the Auditor General's report he notes: "We found that general long-standing problems in federal emergency planning were not being addressed within a reasonable timeframe". Five years after the Auditor General raised the issue in 1987, part two of a national earthquake support plan is still being worked on.
The Auditor General concludes: "In our opinion the delays are the result of several factors including interdepartmental jurisdictional disputes, allocation of resources to other priorities, the complexity of co-ordinating plans with the provinces and a lack of sense of urgency perhaps due to the absence of a recent major disaster in Canada".
It is to the shame of this government and to the ministers responsible, in this case the successive Ministers of National Defence, that we are still not ready to face the consequence of a major earthquake disaster on the west coast.
I call on the government to take the necessary leadership, not to wait until we have a disaster, but in fact to act now. Give those responsible the necessary resources to move so that a potential disaster can be met.
The Auditor General's report again notes that the Geological Survey of Canada, which is part of the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources, has indicated that it feels a compelling requirement to determine if there is evidence to indicate that earthquake catastrophes could take place in the immediate future on Vancouver Island. There are ways to test the chances of an earthquake happening in this area in the immediate future. However, the Auditor General says: "The GSC states it has limited funds for these and related projects".
Now this government can find funds for cold war military hardware and equipment. It can find funds for helicopters designed to deal with the cold war which is over and to hunt submarines which are no longer a threat to our security. But it cannot find the funds according to the Auditor General to deal with a real threat to the lives of hundreds of thousands of people on the west coast of Canada.
I ask the government as it puts through this so-called housekeeping legislation to take its responsibilities seriously and to hear what is being said by the Auditor
Government Orders
General and by the people of our area before it is too late. The warning has been sounded. I ask the government to respond.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS) ACT 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to address the aspects of this bill which relate to the merger of the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and the Canada Council.
The bill would wind up SSHRC as it is known, the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council, and transfer its programs to the Canada Council. This change was announced in the February 1992 budget without any prior consultation or public study of the matter. It came as a complete surprise and shock to the communities concerned. It is important to note that both the artistic and research communities are opposed to this proposal.
To briefly review the history, in 1978 after much consultation and study the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council was established. The activities relating to research in the social sciences and humanities which were previously conducted under the auspices of the Canada Council were transferred to an independent agency. At the time, this move recognized the growing importance of social sciences and humanities research to Canada's over-all science and economic effort and gave social sciences and humanities research the needed autonomy and profile.
It is important to mention some of the disciplines covered by the social sciences. They include: economics, political science, psychology, sociology, history, law, management, education, journalism, demography, science policy and the study of languages.
We spend a great deal of time reflecting on what we have to do as a country to improve our economic circumstances and to compete in fiercely competitive world markets. One of the factors for which the Japanese have known such important economic success is the quality circle. This was not invented by an engineer or by a scientist, but by a social scientist, a professor of management. It is an indication that innovations which take place in our economy do not come solely from the fields of the natural sciences and engineering.
The government has said that the interests of the artistic and research communities will be protected. The government has not convinced the communities concerned by this bill. Despite assurances, they remain opposed.

February 1, 1993
Government Orders
I have received perhaps 100 letters from different groups from across Canada including: the University of Ottawa, the school of graduate research; the University of Montreal, the law faculty, the geography department, the education department; Laval, the department of political science; the University of Winnipeg, the vicepresident of academics; Acadia University, the department of political science; the University of Western Ontario, the department of anthropology.
Thousands of researchers across the country are opposed to this legislation. They remain opposed to it despite the assurances the government has provided. I would like to read into the record excerpts from the letters I have received.

The Department of Education of the University of Montreal: "For researchers in education, complex problems such as illiteracy, dropping out of school and multi-ethnic schools require increased funding beyond present levels. We are concerned that the administrative restructuring which has taken place may cause the funding community to lose interest in subsidizing academic research in the human sciences and thus reduce the support required to ensure continuity". This letter is from the vice-principal of graduate studies and research at the University of Montreal.
From Laval University, at the department of school administration and policy, the department's director, Mr. Jean Moisset, wrote to Mr. Ricard, chairman of the Standing Committee of the House of Commons on Industry, Science and Technology, last March. He said: "I was astonished and extremely disturbed to hear about the planned amalgamation of the Humanities Research Council with the Canada Council".
He went on to say: "It is surprising, to say the least, that one should have chosen this crucial time in our history, marked by so many serious educational, socioeconomic and political problems, to attempt to remove from the social sciences sector one of the most reliable expressions of its specific identity and one of its driving forces: its Research Council".
As I said before, I could quote from hundreds of similar letters.

While the two communities remain opposed, as I have indicated, the research community represented by the Association of Universities and Colleges of Canada and the artistic community represented by the Canadian Conference of the Arts have developed a compromise position.
Again, their first wish is that this bill would be withdrawn. In their letter of December 7 to the Minister of Communications, signed by representatives of both of these organizations, they state: "We would prefer that the government not proceed with Part III of Bill C-92 at this time".
However, if the government is determined to do so, they ask for a number of amendments. First, they would repeal the Canada Council Act and create a new agency to be known as the Canada Council for the Arts and for Research in the Social Sciences and Humanities. The second amendment which I would like to quote is that a person would not be eligible to be appointed as a member of the new council if the person does not have the knowledge or experience that will assist the council in fulfilling one of its functions.
These are just two of a number of amendments that have been forwarded to the Minister of Communications.
To this date there has been no formal response from the government, but I would certainly hope that in committee the government would study this proposal seriously and indeed accept it, if the government is not prepared to come to its senses and just do away with this ill-advised merger.
I would like to conclude in noting that we are often told that budgetary factors are at the source of a change of this nature. Again, the government has really provided no evidence that there are going to be any substantial savings as a result of this merger. On the contrary, it seems that the damage that will be created by the harm to two agencies which have well represented their respective communities could exceed any benefits that have been suggested by the government.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS) ACT 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Bill C-93 has been placed before us today under the pretext of saving money and consolidating efforts. It is the old cliche: the bigger you make things the better they are. The fact is that the bigger you make them the more you lose control of what is going on.
February 1, 1993

Bill C-93 provides for the termination of certain government bodies or the merging of certain government organizations into other government bodies. By the time this Parliament is over, this government will have the management areas of the Public Service of Canada so mixed up no one will know where they are going.
I want to take a case in point. On the Emergency Preparedness Canada organization set up by the hon. member from the Wellington area when he was Minister of National Defence, he brought the bill to set up Emergency Preparedness Canada into this House with all the fanfare of the greatest thing we have seen since sliced bread.
It was a good idea. It has been a good organization in the sense that the people in Emergency Preparedness Canada are dedicated to that organization. What do they do? They train people from all across the country on safety and how to handle emergency situations of all kinds. They have operated as effectively and thoroughly as they could with very little money put in to back them up on the most important objective that any national government could put into effect, that of trying to create co-ordinated emergency measures organizations across this country.
When presenting the budget of February 25, the Minister of Finance announced on that date that Emergency Preparedness Canada would be taken out of its own single operation and would become part of the Department of National Defence. Again, Mr. Speaker, you had this great birth of Emergency Preparedness Canada with some outstanding people working in it. Their single objective was to run classes for municipalities all over this country. They brought in business corporations and taught them how to handle emergencies. They brought in provincial departments, federal departments and all kinds of agencies and ran Emergency Preparedness Canada and how to handle emergencies of all kinds.
Examples of some of the things that they were doing were Canada's emergency response system: who is responsible, taking some of the bedlam out of the organization when emergencies occur, family emergency preparedness, municipal emergency preparedness, the
Government Orders
federal role in emergency preparedness, disaster financial assistance arrangements, emergency response and business resumption planning, emergency food and water pack, essentials of life, blueprint for major catastrophes, what the Government of Canada has done to be prepared for a catastrophic earthquake, earthquake preparedness, people with disabilities, earthquake check list, forest fires, floods. We have it all. They have been doing a fantastic job.
The Auditor General of Canada was absolutely correct in his report when he said that here we have a Government of Canada that set up this agency to do a job and then walked away from it and left it with very little to do that job. Now it is turning around and putting it into the Department of National Defence. The Department of National Defence is certainly a very favourite department of mine in government. The Department of National Defence has all kinds of duties of its own to perform and it wants to perform them well: peacekeeping, their own training programs.
It is called into emergencies of all kinds and it can play a very effective role in backing up Emergency Preparedness Canada, but what is the guarantee that Emergency Preparedness Canada is going to be given any higher profile within the Department of National Defence than it now has when it is standing on its own?
There is no question whatsoever but that Emergency Preparedness Canada should be left alone, left where it is now, because it has the authority and the ability to co-ordinate with all government departments, the ability to co-ordinate with the provinces and with municipalities and whatever. It should be left alone. In the interests of the safety of the Canadian people all over this country, it should be given the resources and the facilities to do its job well so that every municipality, every province, all departments of government-federally and provincial-ly-and the territories will know where they are going when an emergency occurs because there will be a co-ordinated plan and because you will have people in that organization who have been trained in that region of Canada by Emergency Preparedness Canada to do the job when those emergencies occur.

February 1, 1993
Government Orders
The previous Minister of National Defence, and I say this with some regret, spent more time looking around the country for another location for the training centre of Emergency Preparedness Canada, which is presently located in Arnprior, Ontario, than he spent on trying to support the organization itself.
There is no question but that we should vote against this bill because Emergency Preparedness Canada is one of the greatest things that has happened here. The Minister of National Defence at the time, the hon. member for Wellington and about three other counties, I cannot name them offhand right now, came in here with great enthusiasm and he got co-operation from the opposition at the time to set up Emergency Preparedness Canada. We have some very, very fine public servants in that organization who are capable and have indeed proven that they are capable of working with municipalities, corporations, business organizations, provincial departments, federal departments and organizations in the training process.
What would happen today if there were a serious earthquake in Canada? Everybody would be wringing their hands and saying isn't this terrible and so on, and it would be. What would be even more terrible would be that the Government of Canada would not be able to play a major role because it is not financing the very agency which it set up to handle such training for those people, namely Emergency Preparedness Canada.
If you are going to set something up and brag about it, for heaven's sake give it a chance to do the job. That is another terminology that was thrown out at the time: We are going to set up this agency to train the people across the country in emergencies; everybody is going to know how to handle emergencies, and we are going to give them the tools to do the job.
How often have we heard the Prime Minister use this very expression: "We are going to give the people the tools to do the job"? I have been very close to the Auditor General. I piloted this bill through the House setting up Emergency Preparedness Canada for the opposition, and we co-operated very closely in setting it
up because it was something good for the country. But it is only good if it is allowed to work.
I think it is a disgrace today for the government to be taking Emergency Preparedness Canada out of its own element where it can zero in and do things entirely on its own and put it in a larger government department where we do not know what kind of priority is going to be given to it. As an agency it still has the right to call upon all departments and the total forces of the Department of National Defence to help it out in times of emergeny.
I am going to close on that. I wanted to say a word about the Canadian Commercial Corporation and its tremendous job but I do not have the time.

Mr. Speaker, I would also like to contribute to this debate. Given that time is short, my intervention will be likewise.
My community also has some concerns about this particular Bill C-93. The community in my riding has been informed that the existing programs under SSHRC, the budget and administrative personnel will remain intact under the new council, although the organization's function and funding of the new ageny are undefined in this legislation. Therefore, our community in Hamilton-in particular McMaster University-says that the preservation of the research budget, a fair and balanced representation on the council and the provision of strong, progressive leadership with a commitment to a consultative process are key issues. The operative word is consultative.
If it is the government's objective to more effectively serve the Canadian people, as members opposite have so often repeated throughout this day, then I want to put on the record the concerns of the vice-president of research at McMaster University, Mr. Ron F. Childs. He writes:
"(1) We would urge that the budget for the research and scholarship activities of the humanities and social sciences community not only be protected, but more importantly, that it continues to grow relative to the funding for the Medical Research Council and the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council.
February 1, 1993

Government Orders
(2)	We would urge that humanities and social scientists be adequately represented on the council with the appointment of internationally recognized active researchers.
(3)	We would urge that great care be taken in appointing a president of the new council. The president of the council must provide leadership that unites and builds on the common interests of the arts and research communities. The result of the government's decision on the dissolution of SSHRC and the creation of a new agency has created an unsettling environment upon which the future of the arts and research communities must be built".

Mr. Speaker, along the same lines as my colleague from Hamilton West, I also have received a number of representations from the University of Ottawa as well as Carleton University and from a third university in my riding, Saint Paul University. Professors from those universities have indicated their concerns about the manner in which the government has proceeded with this part of the act.
In fact, this is not the first time we have seen something like this. Both councils were joined together in 1978. Through proper consultation in 1978, the two were separated. The councils for the arts and for social sciences and humanities each served different purposes even though they are both in the field of education.
I have been told that no proper consultation has taken place and that is a concern. One would wonder why the government would not have spent a little time in order to deal with the concerns of both councils. As it is, the research in SSHRC over the past three years has been subjected to a lot of pressure by the government when it came to their budget allocation.
By itself, that is a big load to carry on its own. Now that both councils are combined, they are going to see even more pressures on them when it comes to budget allocations and when it comes to the representation on this new council.
For the benefit of everybody, including those who are in the industry in the educational field, maybe the government should defer that part of the act until such a time as proper consultations have taken place. The membership is in excess of 14,000 across Canada. The representative of that membership is telling us that the government has not properly consulted them and taken their concerns into consideration. It has not really reflected on their wishes. One would say that the government has done something wrong. It should defer its decisions on this matter.
I wanted to say this positively. I do not want to sound as being on the negative side of things. The government will do the right thing by deferring this part of the act because the Liberal Party has gone on the record as opposing the marriage between those two councils. It is not because we do not like streamlining, but basically we believe that those two councils serve different purposes even though both of them are in the field of education.
To that extent I would like to call upon the government for the deferral of this part of the act.

subtopic: BUDGET IMPLEMENTATION (GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS) ACT 1992 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have before us another example of the government making a policy decision which has the potential to have a major impact on Canada's ability to compete in the world and to function effectively as a society without any consultation at all with the appropriate groups.
This is a wide-ranging piece of legislation making large numbers of changes in structure. It brings together organizations whose interests are not necessarily the same. It puts them into larger groups rather than diffusing power and decision making in our society and making sure that decisions are made close to where they are going to be implemented and where those people who are making those decisions have the best, most up-to-date knowledge of the situations which are being addressed. Rather than bringing decision making to the communities, the government is centralizing decision making and indeed creating entities which do not very well fit together.

Government Orders
I would like to refer to two of these in the context of my remarks to point out how inappropriate this approach is in dealing with organizations for which the government is responsible. I will comment on the suggestion in this legislation that the Canada Council and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council deal together as one. I will also comment on the proposal which would link the Cape Breton Development Corporation with ACOA.
Neither of these are wise moves. Neither of them will give rise to any benefits to the communities they serve. If the government's only response is that it wants to save money in this consolidation process, that may be possible, but we will not have more effective decision making and more effective organizations in Canada.
A critical point which has been raised is that there has been no consultation at all with the affected groups prior to the implementation of this legislation. There was no consultation prior to the finance minister's statement. In particular, with regard to Canada Council and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council, this will be reversing a decision which took place 14 years ago to separate these two organizations precisely because one organization representing some 200,000 artists in Canada and the other organization representing social sciences and humanities research in almost 100 universities and colleges did not fit and work together.
The decision to split them up was carried out after much consultation and was well received by the communities themselves. Both of those communities are opposed to the amalgamation of these two quite different organizations. One deals with funding support for the arts and the other deals with funding support for social sciences and humanities. Neither of these will be well served by the amalgamation of them.
One thing we should always worry about with this government is whether or not this amalgamation is the beginning of restrictions on funding available to the organization. If this merger were to go through we would have artists, social scientists and those in the humanities making decisions over where funding dollars might go, where research dollars might go and where support dollars might go.
As was recognized some 14 years ago, there is no clear link between the arts on the one hand and social sciences and humanities on the other such that would make an organization like this work effectively. There was no consultation. It does not make sense. It is not going to give rise to appropriate concentration on the issues which are faced by both the arts and the social sciences and humanities.
As the constituencies have indicated, the most effective situation and the best solution here would be to scrap the suggestion for a merger between the Canada Council and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and leave them as they are.
The other merger I would like to deal with is that which will affect most deeply Cape Breton. There has not been a great deal of success in the organizations which have had the objective of generating jobs in Cape Breton. The Nova Scotia economy in general and the Cape Breton economy in particular have never really recovered from the 1981 recession. That happens also to be the case for most of the regions of Canada and certainly it applies to my province also. For example jobs in the goods producing industries in 1982 were about
87,000	in Nova Scotia. They rose to 101,000 in 1988 prior to the implementation of the free trade agreement and the ever stronger enforcement of this government's economic strategies when they fell to 86,000 in 1991; a loss of 15,000 jobs in goods producing industries in Nova Scotia.
In particular, personal income in Cape Breton was about 84 per cent of the Nova Scotia average and 68 per cent of the Canadian average. Averages have been falling in Cape Breton and Nova Scotia for much of the last decade.
Therefore the approach that this government has taken with regard to the economy in Cape Breton has not worked, neither has it worked with regard to the wider application of ACOA.
However nothing good can be served by joining these organizations together, by making them bigger and by moving the decision-making away from Cape Breton and putting it into the context of the whole of Atlantic Canada.

Once again there was no consultation. Once again this is not something that will benefit Cape Breton, the economy of Atlantic Canada or the economy and society of Canada. Those are just two examples in which there was no consultation and in which bigger bodies are being created when we should be really thinking about spreading the decision-making around.
As is so much of the case with this government's decision-making, this is wrong-headed. It will not help. It will make matters worse. The only effective thing to do with this legislation is to vote against it.
